SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Iustice Shallow, Slender, Sir Hugh Euans, Master Page, Falstoffe, Bardolph, Nym, Pistoll, Anne Page, Mistreſſe Ford, Mistreſſe Page, Simple

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shallow.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Hugh, perswade me not: I will make a Star-Chamber matter of it, if hee were twenty Sir Iohn Falstoffs, he ſhall not abuse Robert Shallow Esquire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: In the County of Glocester, Iustice of Peace and Coram.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: I (Cosen Slender) and Cust-alorum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and Ratolorum too; and a Gentleman borne
(Master Parson) who writes himselfe Armigero, in any
Bill, Warrant, Quittance, or Obligation, Armigero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: I that I doe, and haue done any time these three hundred yeeres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: All his ſucceſſors (gone before him) hath don't: and all his Ancestors (that come after him) may: they may giue the dozen white Luces in their Coate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: It is an olde Coate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: The dozen white Lowses doe become an old Coat well: it agrees well paſſant: It is a familiar beast to man, and ſignifies Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: The Luse is the fresh-fish, the ſalt-fish, is an old
Coate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I may quarter (Coz).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: You may, by marrying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a whit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes per-lady: if he ha's a quarter of your coat, there is but three Skirts for your ſelfe, in my ſimple con-iectures; but that is all one: if Sir Iohn Falstaffe haue committed disparagements vnto you, I am of the Church and will be glad to do my beneuolence, to make attone-ments and compremises betweene you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: The Councell ſhall heare it, it is a Riot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not meet the Councell heare a Riot: there is no feare of Got in a Riot: The Councell (looke you) ſhall desire to heare the feare of Got, and not to heare a Riot: take your viza-ments in that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha; o'my life, if I were yong againe, the ſword ſhould end it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: It is petter that friends is the ſword, and end it: and there is also another deuice in my praine, which peraduenture prings goot discretions with it. There is Anne Page, which is daughter to Master Thomas Page, which is pretty virginity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris Anne Page? ſhe has browne haire, and ſpeakes ſmall like a woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: It is that ferry person for all the orld, as iust as you will desire, and ſeuen hundred pounds of Moneyes, and Gold, and Siluer, is her Grand-sire vpon his deaths-bed, (Got deliuer to a ioyfull resurrections) giue, when ſhe is able to ouertake ſeuenteene yeeres old. It were a goot motion, if we leaue our pribbles and prabbles, and desire a marriage betweene Master Abraham, and Mistris Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Did her Grand-sire leaue her ſeauen hundred pound?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and her father is make her a petter penny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I know the young Gentlewoman, ſhe has good gifts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Seuen hundred pounds, and poſſibilities, is goot gifts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Wel, let vs ſee honeſt Mr Page: is Falstaffe there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I tell you a lye? I doe despise a lyer, as I doe despise one that is false, or as I despise one that is not true: the Knight Sir Iohn is there, and I beseech you be ruled by your well-willers: I will peat the doore for Mr. Page. What hoa? Got-pleſſe your house heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Who's there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Here is go't's pleſſing and your friend, and Iu-stice Shallow, and heere yong Master Slender: that perad-uentures ſhall tell you another tale, if matters grow to your likings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad to ſee your Worships well: I thanke you for my Venison Master Shallow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Master Page, I am glad to ſee you: much good doe it your good heart: I wish’d your Venison better, it was ill killd: how doth good Mistreſſe Page? and I thank you alwaies with my heart, la: with my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I thanke you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I thanke you: by yea, and no I doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad to ſee you, good Master Slender.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: How do's your fallow Greyhound, Sir, I heard ſay he was out-run on Cotsall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: It could not be iudg’d, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: You'll not confeſſe: you'll not confeſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: That he will not, ‘tis your fault, ‘tis your fault:
‘tis a good dogge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: A Cur, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir: hee's a good dog, and a faire dog, can there be more ſaid? he is good, and faire. Is Sir Iohn Falstaffe heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, hee is within: and I would I could doe a good office betweene you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: It is ſpoke as a Christians ought to ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath wrong’d me (Master Page.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, he doth in ſome ſort confeſſe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: If it be confeſſed, it is not redreſſed; is not that ſo (M[aster]. Page?) he hath wrong’d me, indeed he hath, at a word he hath: beleeue me, Robert Shallow Esquire, ſaith he is wronged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ma.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes Sir Iohn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, Master Shallow, you'll complaine of me to the King?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Knight, you haue beaten my men, kill’d my deere, and broke open my Lodge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: But not kiſſ’d your Keepers daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, a pin: this ſhall be anſwer’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I will answere it ſtrait, I haue done all this:
That is now anſwer’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: The Councell ſhall know this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twere better for you if it were known in coun-cell: you'll be laugh’d at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Pauca verba; (Sir Iohn) good worts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Good worts? good Cabidge; Slender, I broke your head: what matter haue you against me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſir, I haue matter in my head against you, and against your cony-catching Rascalls, Bardolf, Nym, and Pistoll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: You Banbery Cheese.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I, it is no matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, Mephostophilus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I, it is no matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nym.
SPEECH.LINE: Slice, I ſay; pauca, pauca: Slice, that’s my humor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Where's Simple my man? can you tell, Cosen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, I pray you: now let vs vnderstand: there is three Vmpires in this matter, as I vnderstand; that is, Master Page (fidelicet Master Page,) & there is my ſelfe, (fidelicet my ſelfe) and the three party is (lastly, and fi-nally) mine Host of the Garter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ma.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: We three to hear it, & end it between them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Ferry goo't, I will make a priefe of it in my note-booke, and we wil afterwards orke vpon the cause, with as great discreetly as we can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Pistoll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: He heares with eares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: The Teuill and his Tam: what phrase is this? he heares with eare? why, it is affectations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Pistoll, did you picke M[aster]. Slenders purse?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I, by these gloues did hee, or I would I might neuer come in mine owne great chamber againe else, of ſeauen groates in mill-sixpences, and two Edward Sho-uelboords, that cost me two ſhilling and two pence a peece of Yead Miller: by these gloues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this true, Pistoll?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: No, it is false, if it is a picke-purse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, thou mountaine Forreyner: Sir Iohn, and Master mine, I combat challenge of this Latine Bilbœ: word of deniall in thy labras here; word of denial; froth, and ſcum thou liest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: By these gloues, then 'twas he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nym.
SPEECH.LINE: Be auis’d ſir, and paſſe good humours: I will ſay marry trap with you, if you runne the nut-hooks hu-mor on me, that is the very note of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: By this hat, then he in the red face had it: for though I cannot remember what I did when you made me drunke, yet I am not altogether an aſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay you Scarlet, and Iohn?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, (for my part) I ſay the Gentleman had drunke himselfe out of his fiue ſentences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: It is his fiue ſences: fie, what the ignorance is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: And being fap, ſir, was (as they ſay) casheerd: and ſo conclusions past the Car-eires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I, you ſpake in Latten then to: but ‘tis no mat-ter; Ile nere be drunk whilst I liue againe, but in honeſt, ciuill, godly company for this tricke: if I be drunke, Ile be drunke with those that haue the feare of God, and not with drunken knaues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: So got-udge me, that is a vertuous minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: You heare all these matters deni’d, Gentlemen; you heare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay daughter, carry the wine in, wee'll drinke within.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh heauen: This is Mistreſſe Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Mistris Ford?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris Ford, by my troth you are very wel met: by your leaue good Mistris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Wife, bid these gentlemen welcome: come, we haue a hot Venison pasty to dinner; Come gentle-men, I hope we ſhall drinke downe all vnkindneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather then forty ſhillings I had my booke of Songs and Sonnets heere: How now Simple, where haue you beene? I must wait on my ſelfe, must I? you haue not the booke of Riddles about you, haue you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: Booke of Riddles? why did you not lend it to
Alice Short-cake vpon Alhallowmas last, a fortnight a-fore
Michaelmas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Coz, come Coz, we ſtay for you: a word with you Coz: marry this, Coz: there is as 'twere a ten-der, a kinde of tender, made a farre-off by Sir Hugh here: doe you vnderstand me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir, you ſhall finde me reasonable; if it be ſo,
I ſhall doe that that is reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but vnderstand me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: So I doe Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue eare to his motions; (Mr. Slender) I will description the matter to you, if you be capacity of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I will doe as my Cozen Shallow ſaies: I pray you pardon me, he's a Iustice of Peace in his Coun-trie, ſimple though I ſtand here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: But that is not the question: the question is concerning your marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: I, there's the point Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry is it: the very point of it, to Mi[stris]. An Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Why if it be ſo; I will marry her vpon any rea-sonable demands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: But can you affection the 'o-man, let vs command to know that of your mouth, or of your lips: for diuers Philosophers hold, that the lips is parcell of the mouth: therfore precisely, ca[n] you carry your good wil to y maid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sh.
SPEECH.LINE: Cosen Abraham Slender, can you loue her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope ſir, I will do as it ſhall become one that would doe reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, got's Lords, and his Ladies, you must ſpeake poſſitable, if you can carry-her your desires towards her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: That you must:
Will you, (vpon good dowry) marry her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I will doe a greater thing then that, vpon your request (Cosen) in any reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay conceiue me, conceiue mee, (sweet Coz): What I doe is to pleasure you (Coz:) can you loue the maid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I will marry her (Sir) at your request; but if there bee no great loue in the beginning, yet Heauen may decrease it vpon better acquaintance, when wee are married, and haue more occasion to know one ano-ther: I hope vpon familiarity will grow more content: but if you ſay mary-her, I will mary-her, that I am freely diſſolued, and diſſolutely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a fery discretion-answere; ſaue the fall is in the 'ord, diſſolutely: the ort is (according to our mea-ning) resolutely: his meaning is good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sh.
SPEECH.LINE: I: I thinke my Cosen meant well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: I, or else I would I might be hang’d (la.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sh.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes faire Mistris Anne; would I were yong for your ſake, Mistris Anne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: The dinner is on the Table, my Father desires your worships company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sh.
SPEECH.LINE: I will wait on him, (faire Mistris Anne.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Od's pleſſed-wil: I wil not be abse[n]ce at the grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Wil't please your worship to come in, Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: No, I thank you forsooth, hartely; I am very well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: The dinner attends you, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not a-hungry, I thanke you, forsooth: goe, Sirha, for all you are my man, goe wait vpon my Cosen Shallow: a Iustice of peace ſometime may be beholding to his friend, for a Man; I keepe but three Men, and a Boy yet, till my Mother be dead: but what though, yet I liue like a poore Gentleman borne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I may not goe in without your worship: they will not ſit till you come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: I' faith, ile eate nothing: I thanke you as much as though I did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you Sir walke in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather walke here (I thanke you) I bruiz’d my ſhin th’ other day, with playing at Sword and Dag-ger with a Master of Fence (three veneys for a dish of ſtew’d Prunes) and by my troth, I cannot abide the ſmell of hot meate ſince. Why doe your dogs barke ſo? be there Beares ith' Towne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke there are, Sir, I heard them talk’d of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: I loue the ſport well, but I ſhall as ſoone quarrell at it, as any man in England: you are afraid if you ſee the Beare loose, are you not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I indeede Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: That's meate and drinke to me now: I haue ſeene Saskerson loose, twenty times, and haue taken him by the Chaine: but (I warrant you) the women haue ſo cride and ſhrekt at it, that it past: But women indeede, cannot abide 'em, they are very ill-fauour’d rough things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ma.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, gentle M[aster]. Slender, come; we ſtay for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile eate nothing, I thanke you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ma.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: By cocke and pie, you ſhall not choose, Sir: come, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, pray you lead the way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ma.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris Anne: your ſelfe ſhall goe first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I Sir, pray you keepe on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely I will not goe first: truely-la: I will not doe you that wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile rather be vnmannerly, then troublesome: you doe your ſelfe wrong indeede-la.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Go your waies, and aske of Doctor Caius house, which is the way; and there dwels one Mistris Quickly; which is in the manner of his Nurse; or his dry-Nurse; or his Cooke; or his Laundry; his Washer, and his Ringer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: Well Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, it is petter yet: giue her this letter; for it is a 'oman that altogeathers acquainta[n]ce with Mistris Anne Page; and the Letter is to desire, and require her to ſoli-cite your Masters desires, to Mistris Anne Page: I pray you be gon: I will make an end of my dinner; ther's Pip-pins and Cheese to come.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Falstaffe, Host, Bardolfe, Nym, Pistoll, Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine Host of the Garter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaies my Bully Rooke? ſpeake ſchollerly, and wisely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely mine Host; I must turne away ſome of my followers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: Discard, (bully Hercules) casheere; let them wag; trot, trot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſit at ten pounds a weeke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou'rt an Emperor (Cesar, Keiser and Pheazar)
I will entertaine Bardolfe: he ſhall draw; he ſhall tap; ſaid
I well (bully Hector?)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fa.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe ſo (good mine Host.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſpoke; let him follow; let me ſee thee froth, and liue: I am at a word: follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Bardolfe, follow him: a Tapster is a good trade: an old Cloake, makes a new Ierkin: a wither’d Seruing-man, a fresh Tapster: goe, adew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ba.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a life that I haue desir’d: I will thriue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: O base hungarian wight: wilt y the ſpigot wield.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: He was gotten in drink: is not the humor co[n]ceited?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad I am ſo acquit of this Tinderbox: his
Thefts were too open: his filching was like an vnskilfull
Singer, he kept not time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: The good humor is to ſteale at a minutes rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Conuay: the wise it call: Steale? foh: a fico for the phrase.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſirs, I am almost out at heeles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then let Kibes ensue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: There is no remedy: I must conicatch, I must ſhift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Yong Rauens must haue foode.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Which of you know Ford of this Towne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: I ken the wight: he is of ſubstance good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: My honeſt Lads, I will tell you what I am about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Two yards, and more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: No quips now Pistoll: (Indeede I am in the waste two yards about: but I am now about no waste: I am a-bout thrift) briefely: I doe meane to make loue to Fords wife: I ſpie entertainment in her: ſhee discourses: ſhee carues: ſhe giues the leere of inuitation: I can construe the action of her familier ſtile, & the hardest voice of her behauior (to be english’d rightly) is, I am Sir Iohn Falstafs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath ſtudied her will; and translated her will: out of honesty, into English.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: The Anchor is deepe: will that humor paſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, the report goes, ſhe has all the rule of her husbands Purse: he hath a legend of Angels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: As many diuels entertaine: and to her Boy ſay I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: The humor rises: it is good: humor me the angels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue writ me here a letter to her: & here ano-ther to Pages wife, who euen now gaue mee good eyes too; examind my parts with mo’t iudicious illiads: ſome-times the beame of her view, guilded my foote: ſome-times my portly belly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Then did the Sun on dung-hill ſhine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke thee for that humour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſhe did ſo course o’re my exteriors with ſuch a greedy intention, that the appetite of her eye, did ſeeme to ſcorch me vp like a burning-glaſſe: here's another letter to her: She beares the Purse too: She is a Region in Guiana: all gold, and bountie: I will be Cheaters to them both, and they ſhall be Exchequers to mee: they ſhall be my East and West Indies, and I will trade to them both: Goe, beare thou this Letter to Mistris Page; and thou this to Mistris Ford: we will thriue (Lads) we will thriue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I Sir Pandarus of Troy become,
And by my ſide weare Steele? then Lucifer take all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: I will run no base humor: here take the humor-Letter;
I will keepe the hauior of reputation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Hold Sirha, beare you these Letters tightly,
Saile like my Pinnaſſe to these golden ſhores.
Rogues, hence, auaunt, vanish like haile-stones; goe,
Trudge; plod away ith' hoofe: ſeeke ſhelter, packe:
Falstaffe will learne the honor of the age,
French-thrift, you Rogues, my ſelfe, and ſkirted Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Let Vultures gripe thy guts: for gourd, and
Fullam holds: & high and low beguiles the rich & poore,
Tester ile haue in pouch when thou ſhalt lacke,
Base Phrygian Turke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue opperations,
Which be humors of reuenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou reuenge?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: By Welkin, and her Star.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: With wit, or Steele?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: With both the humors, I:
I will discuſſe the humour of this Loue to Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: And I to Page ſhall eke vnfold
How Falstaffe (varlet vile)
His Doue will proue; his gold will hold,
And his ſoft couch defile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: My humour ſhall not coole: I will incense Ford to deale with poyson: I will poſſeſſe him with yallow-neſſe, for the reuolt of mine is dangerous: that is my true humour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art the Mars of Malecontents: I ſecond thee: troope on.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Mistris Quickly, Simple, Iohn Rugby, Doctor, Caius, Fenton

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: What, Iohn Rugby, I pray thee goe to the Case-ment, and ſee if you can ſee my Master, Master Docter Caius comming: if he doe (I' faith) and finde any body in the house; here will be an old abusing of Gods pati-ence, and the Kings English.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ru.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile goe watch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe, and we'll haue a poſſet for't ſoone at night, (in faith) at the latter end of a Sea-cole-fire: An honeſt, willing, kinde fellow, as euer ſeruant ſhall come in house withall: and I warrant you, no tel-tale, nor no breede-bate: his worst fault is, that he is giuen to prayer; hee is ſomething peeuish that way: but no body but has his fault: but let that paſſe. Peter Simple, you ſay your name is?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: I: for fault of a better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: And Master Slender's your Master?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: I forsooth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Do's he not weare a great round Beard, like a
Glouers pairing-knife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: No forsooth: he hath but a little wee-face; with a little yellow Beard: a Caine colourd Beard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſoftly-sprighted man, is he not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: I forsooth: but he is as tall a man of his hands, as any is betweene this and his head: he hath fought with a Warrener.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſay you: oh, I ſhould remember him: do's he not hold vp his head (as it were?) and ſtrut in his gate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes indeede do's he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, heauen ſend Anne Page, no worse fortune:
Tell Master Parson Euans, I will doe what I can for your
Master: Anne is a good girle, and I wish —

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ru.
SPEECH.LINE: Out alas: here comes my Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſhall all be ſhent: Run in here, good young man: goe into this Cloſſet: he will not ſtay long: what Iohn Rugby? Iohn: what Iohn I ſay? goe Iohn, goe en-quire for my Master, I doubt he be not well, that hee comes not home: (and downe, downe, adowne'a. &c.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: Vat is you ſing? I doe not like des-toyes: pray you goe and vetch me in my Cloſſet, vnboyteere verd; a Box, a greene-a-Box: do intend vat I ſpeake? a greene-a-Box. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I forsooth ile fetch it you: I am glad hee went not in himselfe: if he had found the yong man he would haue bin horne-mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: Fe, fe, fe, fe, mai foy, il fait for ehando, Ie man voi a le
Court la grand affaires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it this Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: Ouy mette le au mon pocket, de-peech quickly:
Vere is dat knaue Rugby?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: What Iohn Rugby, Iohn?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ru.
SPEECH.LINE: Here Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: You are Iohn Rugby, and you are Iacke Rugby: Come, take-a-your Rapier, and come after my heele to the Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ru.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis ready Sir, here in the Porch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: By my trot: I tarry too long: od's-me: que ay ie oublie: dere is ſome Simples in my Cloſſet, dat I vill not for the varld I ſhall leaue behinde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay-me, he'll finde the yong man there, & be mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: O Diable, Diable: vat is in my Cloſſet?
Villanie, La-roone: Rugby, my Rapier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Master be content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore ſhall I be content-a?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: The yong man is an honeſt man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall de honeſt man do in my Cloſſet: dere is no honeſt man dat ſhall come in my Cloſſet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I beseech you be not ſo flegmaticke: heare the truth of it. He came of an errand to mee, from Parson Hugh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: Vell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: I forsooth: to desire her to —

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace-a-your tongue: ſpeake-a-your Tale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: To desire this honeſt Gentlewoman (your Maid) to ſpeake a good word to Mistris Anne Page, for my Ma-ster in the way of Marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: This is all indeede-la: but ile nere put my finger in the fire, and neede not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Hugh ſend-a you? Rugby, ballow mee ſome paper: tarry you a littell-a-while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad he is ſo quiet: if he had bin through-ly moued, you ſhould haue heard him ſo loud, and ſo me-lancholly: but notwithstanding man, Ile doe yœ your Master what good I can: and the very yea, & the no is, y French Doctor my Master, (I may call him my Master, looke you, for I keepe his house; and I wash, ring, brew, bake, ſcowre, dreſſe meat and drinke, make the beds, and doe all my ſelfe.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simp.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis a great charge to come vnder one bodies hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you a-uis’d o'that? you ſhall finde it a great charge: and to be vp early, and down late: but notwith-standing, (to tell you in your eare, I wold haue no words of it) my Master himselfe is in loue with Mistris Anne Page: but notwithstanding that I know Ans mind, that’s neither heere nor there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: You, Iack'Nape: giue-'a this Letter to Sir Hugh, by gar it is a ſhallenge: I will cut his troat in de Parke, and I will teach a ſcuruy Iack-a-nape Priest to meddle, or make:— you may be gon: it is not good you tarry here: by gar I will cut all his two ſtones: by gar, he ſhall not haue a ſtone to throw at his dogge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas: he ſpeakes but for his friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: It is no matter 'a ver dat: do not you tell-a-me dat I ſhall haue Anne Page for my ſelfe? by gar, I vill kill de Iack-Priest: and I haue appointed mine Host of de Iarteer to measure our weapon: by gar, I wil my ſelfe haue Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, the maid loues you, and all ſhall bee well:
We must giue folkes leaue to prate: what the good-ier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: Rugby, come to the Court with me: by gar, if I haue not Anne Page, I ſhall turne your head out of my dore: follow my heeles, Rugby.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall haue An-fooles head of your owne: No, I know Ans mind for that: neuer a woman in Wind-sor knowes more of Ans minde then I doe, nor can doe more then I doe with her, I thanke heauen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fenton.
SPEECH.LINE: Who's with in there, hoa?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Who's there, I troa? Come neere the house I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: How now (good woman) how dost thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: The better that it pleases your good Worship to aske?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: What newes? how do's pretty Mistris Anne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: In truth Sir, and ſhee is pretty, and honeſt, and gentle, and one that is your friend, I can tell you that by the way, I praise heauen for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I doe any good thinkst thou? ſhall I not loose my ſuit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Troth Sir, all is in his hands aboue: but not-withstanding (Master Fenton) Ile be ſworne on a booke ſhee loues you: haue not your Worship a wart aboue your eye?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes marry haue I, what of that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Wel, thereby hangs a tale: good faith, it is ſuch another Nan; (but (I detest) an honeſt maid as euer broke bread: wee had an howres talke of that wart; I ſhall neuer laugh but in that maids company: but (in-deed) ſhee is giuen too much to Allicholy and musing: but for you — well — goe too —

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: I ſhall ſee her to day: hold, there's mo-ney for thee: Let mee haue thy voice in my behalfe: if thou ſeest her before me, commend me. —

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Will I? I faith that wee will: And I will tell your Worship more of the Wart, the next time we haue confidence, and of other woœrs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, fare-well, I am in great haste now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Fare-well to your Worship: truely an honeſt Gentleman: but Anne loues him not: for I know Ans minde as well as another do's: out vpon't: what haue I forgot.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Mistris Page, Mistris Ford, Master Page, Master Ford, Pistoll, Nim, Quickly, Host, Shallow

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What, haue ſcap’d Loue-letters in the holly-day-time of my beauty, and am I now a ſubiect for them? let me ſee? Aske me no reason why I loue you, for though Loue vse Rea-son for his precisian, hee admits him not for his Counsailour: you are not yong, no more am I: goe to then, there's ſimpathie: you are merry, ſo am I: ha, ha, then there's more ſimpathie: you loue ſacke, and ſo do I: would you desire better ſimpathie? Let it ſuffice thee (Mistris Page) at the least if the Loue of Souldier can ſuffice, that I loue thee: I will not ſay pitty mee, ‘tis not a Souldier-like phrase; but I ſay, loue me: By me, thine owne true Knight, by day or night: Or any kinde of light, with all his might, For thee to fight. Iohn Falstaffe. What a Herod of Iurie is this? O wicked, wicked world: One that is well-nye worne to peeces with age To ſhow himselfe a yong Gallant? What an vnwaied Behauiour hath this Flemish drunkard pickt (with The Deuills name) out of my conuersation, that he dares In this manner aſſay me? why, hee hath not beene thrice In my Company: what ſhould I ſay to him? I was then Frugall of my mirth: (heauen forgiue mee:) why Ile Exhibit a Bill in the Parliament for the putting downe of men: how ſhall I be reueng’d on him? for reueng’d I will be? as ſure as his guts are made of puddings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris Page, trust me, I was going to your house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: And trust me, I was comming to you: you looke very ill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay Ile nere beleeue that; I haue to ſhew to the contrary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Faith but you doe in my minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: I doe then: yet I ſay, I could ſhew you to the contrary: O Mistris Page, giue mee ſome counsaile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter, woman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: O woman: if it were not for one trifling re-spect,
I could come to ſuch honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang the trifle (woman) take the honour: what is it? dispence with trifles: what is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: If I would but goe to hell, for an eternall moment, or ſo: I could be knighted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What thou liest? Sir Alice Ford? these Knights will hacke, and ſo thou ſhouldst not alter the ar-ticle of thy Gentry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee burne day-light: heere, read, read: perceiue how I might bee knighted, I ſhall thinke the worse of fat men, as long as I haue an eye to make diffe-rence of mens liking: and yet hee would not ſweare: praise womens modesty: and gaue ſuch orderly and wel-behaued reproofe to al vncomelineſſe, that I would haue ſworne his disposition would haue gone to the truth of his words: but they doe no more adhere and keep place together, then the hundred Psalms to the tune of Green-sleeues: What tempest (I troa) threw this Whale, (with ſo many Tuns of oyle in his belly) a'shoare at Windsor? How ſhall I bee reuenged on him? I thinke the best way were, to entertaine him with hope, till the wicked fire of lust haue melted him in his owne greace: Did you e-uer heare the like?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Letter for letter; but that the name of Page and Ford differs: to thy great comfort in this my-stery of ill opinions, heere's the twyn-brother of thy Let-ter: but let thine inherit first, for I protest mine neuer ſhall: I warrant he hath a thousand of these Letters, writ with blancke-space for different names (sure more): and these are of the ſecond edition: hee will print them out of doubt: for he cares not what hee puts into the preſſe, when he would put vs two: I had rather be a Gianteſſe, and lye vnder Mount Pelion: Well; I will find you twen-tie lasciuious Turtles ere one chaste man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why this is the very ſame: the very hand: the very words: what doth he thinke of vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay I know not: it makes me almost rea-die to wrangle with mine owne honesty: Ile entertaine my ſelfe like one that I am not acquainted withall: for ſure vnleſſe hee know ſome ſtraine in mee, that I know not my ſelfe, hee would neuer haue boorded me in this furie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Boording, call you it? Ile bee ſure to keepe him aboue decke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: So will I: if hee come vnder my hatches, Ile neuer to Sea againe: Let's bee reueng’d on him: let's appoint him a meeting: giue him a ſhow of comfort in his Suit, and lead him on with a fine baited delay, till hee hath pawn’d his horses to mine Host of the Garter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I wil consent to act any villany against him, that may not ſully the charineſſe of our honesty: oh that my husband ſaw this Letter: it would giue eternall food to his iealousie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why look where he comes; and my good man too: hee's as farre from iealousie, as I am from gi-uing him cause, and that (I hope) is an vnmeasurable di-stance. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: You are the happier woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's consult together against this greasie
Knight: Come hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: I hope, it be not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Hope is a curtall-dog in ſome affaires:
Sir Iohn affects thy wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, my wife is not young.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: He woœs both high and low, both rich & poor, both yong and old, one with another (Ford) he loues the Gally-mawfry (Ford) perpend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Loue my wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: With liuer, burning hot: preuent:
Or goe thou like Sir Acteon he, with
Ring-wood at thy heeles: O, odious is the name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What name Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: The horne I ſay: Farewell:
Take heed, haue open eye, for theeues doe foot by night.
Take heed, ere ſommer comes, or Cuckoo-birds do ſing.
Away ſir Corporall Nim:
Beleeue it (Page) he ſpeakes ſence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I will be patient: I will find out this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nim.
SPEECH.LINE: And this is true: I like not the humor of lying: hee hath wronged mee in ſome humors: I ſhould haue borne the humour’d Letter to her: but I haue a ſword: and it ſhall bite vpon my neceſſitie: he loues your wife; There's the ſhort and the long: My name is Corporall Nim: I ſpeak, and I auouch; ‘tis true: my name is Nim: and Falstaffe loues your wife: adieu, I loue not the hu-mour of bread and cheese: adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: The humour of it (quoth 'a?) heere's a fellow frights English out of his wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſeeke out Falstaffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer heard ſuch a drawling-affecting rogue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: If I doe finde it: well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not beleeue ſuch a Cataian, though the
Priest o' th’ Towne commended him for a true man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twas a good ſensible fellow: well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Meg?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Whether goe you (George?) harke you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: How now (sweet Frank) why art thou me-lancholy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I melancholy? I am not melancholy:
Get you home: goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, thou hast ſome crochets in thy head,
Now: will you goe, Mistris Page?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue with you: you'll come to dinner
George? Looke who comes yonder: ſhee ſhall bee our
Meſſenger to this paltrie Knight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Trust me, I thought on her: ſhee'll fit it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: You are come to ſee my daughter Anne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: I forsooth: and I pray how do's good Mistreſſe
Anne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Go in with vs and ſee: we haue an houres talke with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Master Ford?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: You heard what this knaue told me, did you not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, and you heard what the other told me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe you thinke there is truth in them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang 'em ſlaues: I doe not thinke the Knight would offer it: But these that accuse him in his intent towards our wiues, are a yoake of his discarded men: ve-ry rogues, now they be out of ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Were they his men?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry were they.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I like it neuer the beter for that,
Do's he lye at the Garter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I marry do's he: if hee ſhould intend this voy-age toward my wife, I would turne her loose to him; and what hee gets more of her, then ſharpe words, let it lye on my head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe not misdoubt my wife: but I would bee loath to turne them together: a man may be too confi-dent: I would haue nothing lye on my head: I cannot be thus ſatisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke where my ranting-Host of the Garter comes: there is eyther liquor in his pate, or mony in his purse, when hee lookes ſo merrily: How now mine Host?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Bully-Rooke: thou'rt a Gentleman
Caueleiro Iustice, I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: I follow, (mine Host) I follow: Good-euen, and twenty (good Master Page.) Master Page, wil you go with vs? we haue ſport in hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell him Caueleiro-Iustice: tell him Bully-Rooke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shall.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, there is a fray to be fought, betweene Sir
Hugh the Welch Priest, and Caius the French Doctor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Good mine Host o'th’ Garter: a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaist thou, my Bully-Rooke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you goe with vs to behold it? My merry Host hath had the measuring of their weapons; and (I thinke) hath appointed them contrary places: for (be-leeue mee) I heare the Parson is no Iester: harke, I will tell you what our ſport ſhall be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Hast thou no ſuit against my Knight? my guest-Caualeire?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: None, I protest: but Ile giue you a pottle of burn’d ſacke, to giue me recourse to him, and tell him my name is Broome: onely for a iest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: My hand, (Bully:) thou ſhalt haue egreſſe and regreſſe, (said I well?) and thy name ſhall be Broome. It is a merry Knight: will you goe An-heires?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue with you mine Host.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue heard the French-man hath good ſkill in his Rapier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut ſir: I could haue told you more: In these times you ſtand on distance: your Paſſes, Stoccado's, and I know not what: ‘tis the heart (Master Page) ‘tis heere, ‘tis heere: I haue ſeene the time, with my long-sword, I would haue made you fowre tall fellowes ſkippe like Rattes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere boyes, heere, heere: ſhall we wag?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue with you: I had rather heare them ſcold, then fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Though Page be a ſecure foole, and ſtands ſo firmely on his wiues frailty; yet, I cannot put-off my o-pinion ſo easily: ſhe was in his company at Pages house: and what they made there, I know not. Well, I wil looke further into't, and I haue a disguise, to ſound Falstaffe; if I finde her honeſt, I loose not my labor: if ſhe be other-wise, ‘tis labour well bestowed.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Falstaffe, Pistoll, Robin, Quickly, Bardolffe, Ford

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not lend thee a penny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then the world's mine Oyster, which I, with ſword will open.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a penny: I haue beene content (Sir,) you ſhould lay my countenance to pawne: I haue grated vp-on my good friends for three Repreeues for you, and your Coach-fellow Nim; or else you had look’d through the grate, like a Geminy of Baboones: I am damn’d in hell, for ſwearing to Gentlemen my friends, you were good Souldiers, and tall-fellowes. And when Mistreſſe Briget lost the handle of her Fan, I took't vpon mine ho-nour thou hadst it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Didst not thou ſhare? hadst thou not fifteene pence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Reason, you roague, reason: thinkst thou Ile en-danger my ſoule, gratis? at a word, hang no more about mee, I am no gibbet for you: goe, a ſhort knife, and a throng, to your Mannor of Pickt-hatch: goe, you'll not beare a Letter for mee you roague? you ſtand vpon your honor: why, (thou vnconfinable baseneſſe) it is as much as I can doe to keepe the termes of my honor precise: I, I, I my ſelfe ſometimes, leauing the feare of heauen on the left hand, and hiding mine honor in my neceſſity, am faine to ſhufflle: to hedge, and to lurch, and yet, you Rogue, will en-sconce your raggs; your Cat-a-Moun-taine-lookes, your red-lattice phrases, and your bold-beating-oathes, vnder the ſhelter of your honor? you will not doe it? you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe relent: what would thou more of man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robin.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, here's a woman would ſpeake with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Let her approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue your worship good morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Good-morrow, good-wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo, and't please your worship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Good maid then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile be ſworne,
As my mother was the first houre I was borne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe beleeue the ſwearer; what with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I vouch-safe your worship a word, or two?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Two thousand (faire woman) and ile vouchsafe thee the hearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: There is one Mistreſſe Ford, (Sir) I pray come a little neerer this waies: I my ſelfe dwell with M[aster]. Doctor Caius:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, on; Mistreſſe Ford, you ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Your worship ſaies very true: I pray your wor-ship come a little neerer this waies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant thee, no-bodie heares: mine owne people, mine owne people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Are they ſo? heauen-bleſſe them, and make them his Seruants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well; Mistreſſe Ford, what of her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Sir; ſhee's a good-creature; Lord, Lord, your Worship's a wanton: well: heauen forgiue you, and all of vs, I pray —.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistreſſe Ford: come, Mistreſſe Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry this is the ſhort, and the long of it: you haue brought her into ſuch a Canaries, as ‘tis wonder-full: the best Courtier of them all (when the Court lay at Windsor) could neuer haue brought her to ſuch a Ca-narie: yet there has beene Knights, and Lords, and Gen-tlemen, with their Coaches; I warrant you Coach after Coach, letter after letter, gift after gift, ſmelling ſo ſweet-ly; all Muske, and ſo rushling, I warrant you, in ſilke and golde, and in ſuch alligant termes, and in ſuch wine and ſuger of the best, and the fairest, that would haue wonne any womans heart: and I warrant you, they could neuer get an eye-winke of her: I had my ſelfe twentie Angels giuen me this morning, but I defie all Angels (in any ſuch ſort, as they ſay) but in the way of honesty: and I warrant you, they could neuer get her ſo much as ſippe on a cup with the prowdest of them all, and yet there has beene Earles: nay, (which is more) Pentioners, but I warrant you all is one with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: But what ſaies ſhee to mee? be briefe my good ſhee- Mercurie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, ſhe hath receiu’d your Letter: for the which ſhe thankes you a thousand times; and ſhe giues you to notifie, that her husband will be absence from his house, betweene ten and eleuen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ten, and eleuen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: I, forsooth: and then you may come and ſee the picture (she ſayes) that you wot of: Master Ford her hus-band will be from home: alas, the ſweet woman leades an ill life with him: hee's a very iealousie-man; ſhe leads a very frampold life with him, (good hart.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ten, and eleuen.
Woman, commend me to her, I will not faile her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, you ſay well: But I haue another meſſen-ger to your worship: Mistreſſe Page hath her heartie commendations to you to: and let mee tell you in your eare, ſhee's as fartuous a ciuill modest wife, and one (I tell you) that will not miſſe you morning nor euening prayer, as any is in Windsor, who ere bee the other: and ſhee bade me tell your worship, that her husband is ſel-dome from home, but ſhe hopes there will come a time. I neuer knew a woman ſo doate vpon a man; ſurely I thinke you haue charmes, la: yes in truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I, I aſſure thee; ſetting the attraction of my good parts aside, I haue no other charmes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Bleſſing on your heart for't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: But I pray thee tell me this: has Fords wife, and
Pages wife acquainted each other, how they loue me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: That were a iest indeed: they haue not ſo little grace I hope, that were a tricke indeed: But Mistris Page would desire you to ſend her your little Page of al loues: her husband has a maruellous infectio[n] to the little Page: and truely Master Page is an honeſt man: neuer a wife in Windsor leades a better life then ſhe do's: doe what ſhee will, ſay what ſhe will, take all, pay all, goe to bed when ſhe list, rise when ſhe list, all is as ſhe will: and truly ſhe deserues it; for if there be a kinde woman in Windsor, ſhe is one: you must ſend her your Page, no remedie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but doe ſo then, and looke you, hee may come and goe betweene you both: and in any case haue a nay-word, that you may know one anothers minde, and the Boy neuer neede to vnderstand any thing; for ‘tis not good that children ſhould know any wickednes: olde folkes you know, haue discretion, as they ſay, and know the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Farethee-well, commend mee to them both: there's my purse, I am yet thy debter: Boy, goe along with this woman, this newes distracts me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: This Puncke is one of Cupids Carriers,
Clap on more ſailes, pursue: vp with your ſights:
Giue fire: ſhe is my prize, or Ocean whelme them all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Saist thou ſo (old Iacke) go thy waies: Ile make more of thy olde body then I haue done: will they yet looke after thee? wilt thou after the expence of ſo much money, be now a gainer? good Body, I thanke thee: let them ſay ‘tis groſſely done, ſo it bee fairely done, no matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn, there's one Master Broome below would faine ſpeake with you, and be acquainted with you; and hath ſent your worship a mornings draught of Sacke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Broome is his name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Call him in: ſuch Broomes are welcome to mee, that ore'flowes ſuch liquor: ah ha, Mistreſſe Ford and Mi-streſſe Page, haue I encompaſſ’d you? goe to, via.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Bleſſe you ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: And you ſir: would you ſpeake with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I make bold, to preſſe, with ſo little prepara-tion vpon you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: You'r welcome, what’s your will? giue vs leaue
Drawer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I am a Gentleman that haue ſpent much, my name is Broome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Master Broome, I desire more acquaintance of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Sir Iohn, I ſue for yours: not to charge you, for I must let you vnderstand, I thinke my ſelfe in better plight for a Lender, then you are: the which hath ſomething emboldned me to this vnseason’d intrusion: for they ſay, if money goe before, all waies doe lye open.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Money is a good Souldier (Sir) and will on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Troth, and I haue a bag of money heere trou-bles me: if you will helpe to beare it (Sir Iohn) take all, or halfe, for easing me of the carriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I know not how I may deserue to bee your
Porter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell you ſir, if you will giue mee the hea-ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake (good Master Broome) I ſhall be glad to be your Seruant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I heare you are a Scholler: (I will be briefe with you) and you haue been a man long knowne to me, though I had neuer ſo good means as desire, to make my ſelfe acquainted with you. I ſhall discouer a thing to you, wherein I must very much lay open mine owne im-perfection: but (good Sir Iohn) as you haue one eye vp-on my follies, as you heare them vnfolded, turne another into the Register of your owne, that I may paſſe with a reproofe the easier, ſith you your ſelfe know how easie it is to be ſuch an offender.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Very well Sir, proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: There is a Gentlewoman in this Towne, her husbands name is Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue long lou’d her, and I protest to you, be-stowed much on her: followed her with a doating ob-seruance: Ingroſſ’d opportunities to meete her: fee’d e-uery ſlight occasion that could but nigardly giue mee ſight of her: not only bought many presents to giue her, but haue giuen largely to many, to know what ſhee would haue giuen: briefly, I haue pursu’d her, as Loue hath pursued mee, which hath beene on the wing of all occasions: but whatsœuer I haue merited, either in my minde, or in my meanes, meede I am ſure I haue receiued none, vnleſſe Experience be a Iewell, that I haue purcha-sed at an infinite rate, and that hath taught mee to ſay this, "Loue like a ſhadow flies, when ſubstance Loue pursues, "Pursuing that that flies, and flying what pursues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you receiu’d no promise of ſatisfaction at her hands?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you importun’d her to ſuch a purpose?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Of what qualitie was your loue then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Like a fair house, built on another mans ground, ſo that I haue lost my edifice, by mistaking the place, where I erected it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: To what purpose haue you vnfolded this to me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: When I haue told you that, I haue told you all: Some ſay, that though ſhe appeare honeſt to mee, yet in other places ſhee enlargeth her mirth ſo farre, that there is ſhrewd construction made of her. Now (Sir Iohn) here is the heart of my purpose: you are a gentleman of ex-cellent breeding, admirable discourse, of great admit-tance, authenticke in your place and person, generally allow’d for your many war-like, court-like, and learned preparations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: O Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Beleeue it, for you know it: there is money, ſpend it, ſpend it, ſpend more; ſpend all I haue, onely giue me ſo much of your time in enchange of it, as to lay an amiable ſiege to the honesty of this Fords wife: vse your Art of wooing; win her to consent to you: if any man may, you may as ſoone as any.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Would it apply well to the vehemency of your affection that I ſhould win what you would enioy? Me-thinkes you prescribe to your ſelfe very preposterously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: O, vnderstand my drift: ſhe dwells ſo ſecurely on the excellency of her honor, that the folly of my ſoule dares not present it ſelfe: ſhee is too bright to be look’d against. Now, could I come to her with any detection in my hand; my desires had instance and argument to commend themselues, I could driue her then from the ward of her purity, her reputation, her marriage-vow, and a thousand other her defences, which now are too-too ſtrongly embattaild against me: what ſay you too't, Sir Iohn?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Master Broome, I will first make bold with your money: next, giue mee your hand: and last, as I am a gentleman, you ſhall, if you will, enioy Fords wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: O good Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay you ſhall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Want no money (Sir Iohn) you ſhall want none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Want no Mistreſſe Ford (Master Broome) you ſhall want none: I ſhall be with her (I may tell you) by her owne appointment, euen as you came in to me, her aſſi-stant, or goe-betweene, parted from me: I ſay I ſhall be with her betweene ten and eleuen: for at that time the iealious-rascally-knaue her husband will be forth: come you to me at night, you ſhall know how I ſpeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I am blest in your acquaintance: do you know
Ford Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang him (poore Cuckoldly knaue) I know him not: yet I wrong him to call him poore: They ſay the iealous wittolly-knaue hath maſſes of money, for the which his wife ſeemes to me well-fauourd: I will vse her as the key of the Cuckoldly-rogues Coffer, & ther's my haruest-home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I would you knew Ford, ſir, that you might a-uoid him, if you ſaw him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang him, mechanicall-salt-butter rogue; I wil ſtare him out of his wits: I will awe-him with my cud-gell: it ſhall hang like a Meteor ore the Cuckolds horns: Master Broome, thou ſhalt know, I will predominate o-uer the pezant, and thou ſhalt lye with his wife. Come to me ſoone at night: Ford's a knaue, and I will aggra-uate his ſtile: thou (Master Broome) ſhalt know him for knaue, and Cuckold. Come to me ſoone at night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What a damn’d Epicurian-Rascall is this? my heart is ready to cracke with impatience: who ſaies this is improuident iealousie? my wife hath ſent to him, the howre is fixt, the match is made: would any man haue thought this? ſee the hell of hauing a false woman: my bed ſhall be abus’d, my Coffers ransack’d, my reputati-on gnawne at, and I ſhall not onely receiue this villanous wrong, but ſtand vnder the adoption of abhominable termes, and by him that does mee this wrong: Termes, names: Amaimon ſounds well: Lucifer, well: Barbason, well: yet they are Diuels additions, the names of fiends: But Cuckold, Wittoll, Cuckold? the Diuell himselfe hath not ſuch a name. Page is an Aſſe, a ſecure Aſſe; hee will trust his wife, hee will not be iealous: I will rather trust a Fleming with my butter, Parson Hugh the Welsh-man with my Cheese, an Irish-man with my Aqua-vitae-bottle, or a Theefe to walke my ambling gelding, then my wife with her ſelfe. Then ſhe plots, then ſhee rumi-nates, then ſhee deuises: and what they thinke in their hearts they may effect; they will breake their hearts but they will effect. Heauen bee prais’d for my iealousie: eleuen o' clocke the howre, I will preuent this, detect my wife, bee reueng’d on Falstaffe, and laugh at Page. I will about it, better three houres too ſoone, then a my-nute too late: fie, fie, fie: Cuckold, Cuckold, Cuckold.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Caius, Rugby, Page, Shallow, Slender, Host.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: Iacke Rugby.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rug.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: Vat is the clocke, Iack.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rug.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis past the howre (Sir) that Sir Hugh promis’d to meet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, he has ſaue his ſoule, dat he is no-come: hee has pray his Pible well, dat he is no-come: by gar (Iack Rugby) he is dead already, if he be come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rug.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee is wise Sir: hee knew your worship would kill him if he came.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, de herring is no dead, ſo as I vill kill him: take your Rapier, (Iacke) I vill tell you how I vill kill him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rug.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas ſir, I cannot fence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Villaine, take your Rapier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rug.
SPEECH.LINE: Forbeare: heer's company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Bleſſe thee, bully-Doctor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Saue you Mr. Doctor Caius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Now good Mr. Doctor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Giue you good-morrow, ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: Vat be all you one, two, tree, fowre, come for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: To ſee thee fight, to ſee thee foigne, to ſee thee trauerse, to ſee thee heere, to ſee thee there, to ſee thee paſſe thy puncto, thy ſtock, thy reuerse, thy distance, thy montant: Is he dead, my Ethiopian? Is he dead, my Fran-cisco? ha Bully? what ſaies my Esculapius? my Galien? my heart of Elder? ha? is he dead bully-Stale? is he dead?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, he is de Coward-Iack-Priest of de vorld: he is not ſhow his face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a Castalion-king-Vrinall: Hector of
Greece (my Boy)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you beare witneſſe, that me haue ſtay, ſixe or ſeuen, two tree howres for him, and hee is no-come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: He is the wiser man (M[aster]. Doctor) he is a curer of ſoules, and you a curer of bodies: if you ſhould fight, you goe against the haire of your profeſſions: is it not true, Master Page?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Master Shallow; you haue your ſelfe beene a great fighter, though now a man of peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Body-kins M[aster]. Page, though I now be old, and of the peace; if I ſee a ſword out, my finger itches to make one: though wee are Iustices, and Doctors, and Church-men (M[aster]. Page) wee haue ſome ſalt of our youth in vs, we are the ſons of women (M[aster]. Page.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis true, Mr. Shallow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: It wil be found ſo, (M[aster]. Page:) M[aster]. Doctor Caius, I am come to fetch you home: I am ſworn of the peace: you haue ſhow’d your ſelfe a wise Physician, and Sir Hugh hath ſhowne himselfe a wise and patient Church-man: you must goe with me, M[aster]. Doctor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon, Guest-Iustice; a Mounseur Mocke-water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Mock-vater? vat is dat?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Mock-water, in our English tongue, is Valour
(Bully.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, then I haue as much Mock-vater as de Englishman: ſcuruy-Iack-dog-Priest: by gar, mee vill cut his eares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: He will Clapper-claw thee tightly (Bully.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Clapper-de-claw? vat is dat?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: That is, he will make thee amends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By-gar, me doe looke hee ſhall clapper-de-claw me, for by-gar, me vill haue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: And I will prouoke him to't, or let him wag.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Me tanck you for dat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: And moreouer, (Bully) but first, Mr. Ghuest, and M[aster]. Page, & eeke Caualeiro Slender, goe you through the Towne to Frogmore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: He is there, ſee what humor he is in: and I will bring the Doctor about by the Fields: will it doe well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: We will doe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Adieu, good M[aster]. Doctor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By-gar, me vill kill de Priest, for he ſpeake for a
Iack-an-Ape to Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Let him die: ſheath thy impatience: throw cold water on thy Choller: goe about the fields with mee through Frogmore, I will bring thee where Mistris Anne Page is, at a Farm-house a Feasting: and thou ſhalt woœ her: Cride-game, ſaid I well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By-gar, mee dancke you vor dat: by gar I loue you: and I ſhall procure 'a you de good Guest: de Earle, de Knight, de Lords, de Gentlemen, my patients.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: For the which, I will be thy aduersary toward
Anne Page: ſaid I well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By-gar, ‘tis good: vell ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs wag then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Come at my heeles, Iack Rugby.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Euans, Simple, Page, Shallow, Slender, Host, Caius, Rugby

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you now, good Master Slenders ſeruing-man, and friend Simple by your name; which way haue you look’d for Master Caius, that calls himselfe Doctor of Phisicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Sir, the pittie-ward, the Parke-ward: euery way: olde Windsor way, and euery way but the Towne-way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: I mo’t fehemently desire you, you will also looke that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Pleſſe my ſoule: how full of Chollors I am, and trempling of minde: I ſhall be glad if he haue deceiued me: how melancholies I am? I will knog his Vrinalls a-bout his knaues costard, when I haue good oportunities for the orke: 'Pleſſe my ſoule: To ſhallow Riuers to whose falls: melodious Birds ſings Madrigalls: There will we make our Peds of Roses: and a thousand fragrant posies. To ſhal-low: 'Mercie on mee, I haue a great dispositions to cry. Melodious birds ſing Madrigalls: — When as I ſat in Pa-bilon: and a thousand vagram Posies. To ſhallow, &c.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: Yonder he is comming, this way, Sir Hugh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee's welcome: To ſhallow Riuers, to whose fals:
Heauen prosper the right: what weapons is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: No weapons, Sir: there comes my Master, Mr. Shallow, and another Gentleman; from Frogmore, ouer the ſtile, this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you giue mee my gowne, or else keepe it in your armes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Master Parson? good morrow good
Sir Hugh: keepe a Gamester from the dice, and a good
Studient from his booke, and it is wonderfull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah ſweet Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Saue you, good Sir Hugh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Pleſſe you from his mercy-sake, all of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: What? the Sword, and the Word?
Doe you ſtudy them both, Mr. Parson?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: And youthfull ſtill, in your doublet and hose, this raw-rumaticke day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: There is reasons, and causes for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: We are come to you, to doe a good office, Mr.
Parson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Fery-well: what is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Yonder is a mo’t reuerend Gentleman; who (be-like) hauing receiued wrong by ſome person, is at mo’t odds with his owne grauity and patience, that euer you ſaw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue liued foure-score yeeres, and vpward: I neuer heard a man of his place, grauity, and learning, ſo wide of his owne respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: What is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke you know him: Mr. Doctor Caius the renowned French Physician.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Got's-will, and his paſſion of my heart: I had as lief you would tell me of a meſſe of porredge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: He has no more knowledge in Hibocrates and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Galen
SPEECH.LINE: , and hee is a knaue besides: a cowardly knaue, as you would desires to be acquainted withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant you, hee's the man ſhould fight with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſweet Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: It appeares ſo by his weapons: keepe them a-sunder: here comes Doctor Caius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay good Mr. Parson, keepe in your weapon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: So doe you, good Mr. Doctor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Disarme them, and let them question: let them keepe their limbs whole, and hack our English.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you let-a-mee ſpeake a word with your eare; vherefore vill you not meet-a me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you vse your patience in good time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By-gar, you are de Coward: de Iack dog: Iohn
Ape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you let vs not be laughing-stocks to other mens humors: I desire you in friendship, and I will one way or other make you amends: I will knog your Vrinal about your knaues Cogs-combe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Diable: Iack Rugby: mine Host de Iarteer: haue I not ſtay for him, to kill him? haue I not at de place I did appoint?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: As I am a Christians-soule, now looke you: this is the place appointed, Ile bee iudgement by mine Host of the Garter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, I ſay, Gallia and Gaule, French & Welch,
Soule-Curer, and Body-Curer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I, dat is very good, excellant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, I ſay: heare mine Host of the Garter, Am I politicke? Am I ſubtle? Am I a Machiuell? Shall I loose my Doctor? No, hee giues me the Potions and the Motions. Shall I loose my Parson? my Priest? my Sir Hugh? No, he giues me the Prouerbes, and the No-verbes. Giue me thy hand (Celestiall) ſo: Boyes of Art, I haue deceiu’d you both: I haue directed you to wrong places: your hearts are mighty, your ſkinnes are whole, and let burn’d Sacke be the iſſue: Come, lay their ſwords to pawne: Follow me, Lad of peace, follow, fol-low, follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Trust me, a mad Host: follow Gentlemen, fol-low.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſweet Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha' do I perceiue dat? Haue you make-a-de-sot of vs, ha, ha?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: This is well, he has made vs his vlowting-stog: I desire you that we may be friends: and let vs knog our praines together to be reuenge on this ſame ſcall ſcur-uy-cogging-companion the Host of the Garter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, with all my heart: he promise to bring me where is Anne Page: by gar he deceiue me too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I will ſmite his noddles: pray you follow.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Mist. Page, Robin, Ford, Page, Shallow, Slender, Host, Euans, Caius

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay keepe your way (little Gallant) you were wont to be a follower, but now you are a Leader: whether had you rather lead mine eyes, or eye your ma-sters heeles?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rob.
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather (forsooth) go before you like a man, then follow him like a dwarfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: O you are a flattering boy, now I ſee you'l be a
(Courtier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well met mistris Page, whether go you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly Sir, to ſee your wife, is ſhe at home?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and as idle as ſhe may hang together for want of company: I thinke if your husbands were dead, you two would marry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Be ſure of that, two other husbands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Where had you this pretty weather-cocke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot tell what (the dickens) his name is my husband had him of, what do you cal your Knights name ſirrah?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rob.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn Falstaffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn Falstaffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: He, he, I can neuer hit on's name; there is ſuch a league betweene my goodman, and he: is your Wife at home indeed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed ſhe is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: By your leaue ſir, I am ſicke till I ſee her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Has Page any braines? Hath he any eies? Hath he any thinking? Sure they ſleepe, he hath no vse of them: why this boy will carrie a letter twentie mile as easie, as a Canon will ſhoot point-blanke twelue ſcore: hee pee-ces out his wiues inclination: he giues her folly motion and aduantage: and now ſhe's going to my wife, & Fal-staffes boy with her: A man may heare this ſhowre ſing in the winde; and Falstaffes boy with her: good plots, they are laide, and our reuolted wiues ſhare damnation together. Well, I will take him, then torture my wife, plucke the borrowed vaile of modestie from the ſo-see-ming Mist[ris]. Page, divulge Page himselfe for a ſecure and wilfull Acteon, and to these violent proceedings all my neighbors ſhall cry aime. The clocke giues me my Qu, and my aſſurance bids me ſearch, there I ſhall finde Fal-staffe: I ſhall be rather praisd for this, then mock’d, for it is as poſſitiue, as the earth is firme, that Falstaffe is there: I will go. Shal. Page, &c. Well met Mr Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Trust me, a good knotte; I haue good cheere at home, and I pray you all go with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: I must excuse my ſelfe Mr Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo must I Sir,
We haue appointed to dine with Mistris Anne,
And I would not breake with her for more mony
Then Ile ſpeake of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue linger’d about a match betweene An Page, and my cozen Slender, and this day wee ſhall haue our anſwer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope I haue your good will Father Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue Mr Slender, I ſtand wholly for you,
But my wife (Mr Doctor) is for you altogether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I be-gar, and de Maid is loue-a-me: my nursh-a-Quickly tell me ſo mush.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay you to yong Mr Fenton? He capers, he dances, he has eies of youth: he writes verses, hee ſpeakes holliday, he ſmels April and May, he wil carry’t, he will carry’t, ‘tis in his buttons, he will carry’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Not by my consent I promise you. The Gentle-man is of no hauing, hee kept companie with the wilde Prince, and Pointz: he is of too high a Region, he knows too much: no, hee ſhall not knit a knot in his fortunes, with the finger of my ſubstance: if he take her, let him take her ſimply: the wealth I haue waits on my consent, and my consent goes not that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I beseech you heartily, ſome of you goe home with me to dinner: besides your cheere you ſhall haue ſport, I will ſhew you a monster: Mr Doctor, you ſhal go, ſo ſhall you Mr Page, and you Sir Hugh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, fare you well:
We ſhall haue the freer woing at Mr Pages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Go home Iohn Rugby, I come anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell my hearts, I will to my honeſt Knight
Falstaffe, and drinke Canarie with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke I ſhall drinke in Pipe-wine first with him, Ile make him dance. Will you go Gentles?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Haue with you, to ſee this Monster.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter M. Ford, M. Page, Seruants, Robin, Falstaffe, Ford, Page, Caius, Euans

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What Iohn, what Robert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Quickly, quickly: Is the Buck-basket —

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant. What Robin I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere, ſet it downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue your men the charge, we must be briefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie, as I told you before (Iohn & Robert) be ready here hard-by in the Brew-house, & when I ſo-dainly call you, come forth, and (without any pause, or ſtaggering) take this basket on your ſhoulders: y done, trudge with it in all hast, and carry it among the Whit-sters in Dotchet Mead, and there empty it in the muddie ditch, close by the Thames ſide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: You will do it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I ha told them ouer and ouer, they lacke no direction.
Be gone, and come when you are call’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes little Robin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: How now my Eyas-Musket, what newes with you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rob.
SPEECH.LINE: My M[aster]. Sir Iohn is come in at your backe doore
(Mist[ris]. Ford, and requests your company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: You litle Iack-a-lent, haue you bin true to vs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rob.
SPEECH.LINE: I, Ile be ſworne: my Master knowes not of your being heere: and hath threatned to put me into euerla-sting liberty, if I tell you of it: for he ſweares he'll turne me away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou'rt a good boy: this ſecrecy of thine ſhall be a Tailor to thee, and ſhal make thee a new dou-blet and hose. Ile go hide me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Do ſo: go tell thy Master, I am alone: Mi-stris
Page, remember you your Qu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant thee, if I do not act it, hiſſe me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Go-too then: we'l vse this vnwholsome humidity, this groſſe-watry Pumpion; we'll teach him to know Turtles from Iayes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue I caught thee, my heauenly Iewell? Why now let me die, for I haue liu’d long enough: This is the period of my ambition: O this bleſſed houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſweet Sir Iohn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot prate (Mist[ris]. Ford) now ſhall I ſin in my wish; I would thy Husband were dead, Ile ſpeake it before the best Lord, I would make thee my Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I your Lady Sir Iohn? Alas, I ſhould bee a pittifull Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Let the Court of France ſhew me ſuch another: I ſee how thine eye would emulate the Diamond: Thou hast the right arched-beauty of the brow, that becomes the Ship-tyre, the Tyre-valiant, or any Tire of Venetian admittance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: A plaine Kerchiefe, Sir Iohn:
My browes become nothing else, nor that well neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a tyrant to ſay ſo: thou wouldst make an absolute Courtier, and the firme fixture of thy foote, would giue an excellent motion to thy gate, in a ſemi-circled Farthingale. I ſee what thou wert if Fortune thy fœ, were not Nature thy friend: Come, thou canst not hide it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Beleeue me, ther's no ſuch thing in me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: What made me loue thee? Let that perswade thee. Ther's ſomething extraordinary in thee: Come, I cannot cog, and ſay thou art this and that, like a-manie of these lisping-hauthorne buds, that come like women in mens apparrell, and ſmell like Bucklers-berry in ſim-ple time: I cannot, but I loue thee, none but thee; and thou deseru'st it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not betray me ſir, I fear you loue M[istris]. Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou mightst as well ſay, I loue to walke by the Counter-gate, which is as hatefull to me, as the reeke of a Lime-kill.
