SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, heauen knowes how I loue you,
And you ſhall one day finde it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Keepe in that minde, Ile deserue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I must tell you, ſo you doe;
Or else I could not be in that minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rob.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris Ford, Mistris Ford: heere's Mistris Page at the doore, ſweating, and blowing, and looking wildely, and would needs ſpeake with you presently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: She ſhall not ſee me, I will ensconce mee behinde the Arras.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you do ſo, ſhe's a very tatling woman.
Whats the matter? How now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: O mistris Ford what haue you done?
You'r ſham’d, y'are ouerthrowne, y'are vndone for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter, good mistris Page?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: O weladay, mist[ris]. Ford, hauing an honeſt man to your husband, to giue him ſuch cause of ſuspition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What cause of ſuspition?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What cause of ſuspition? Out vpon you:
How am I mistooke in you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why (alas) what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Your husband's comming hether (Woman) with all the Officers in Windsor, to ſearch for a Gentle-man, that he ſayes is heere now in the house; by your consent to take an ill aduantage of his absence: you are vndone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis not ſo, I hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray heauen it be not ſo, that you haue ſuch a man heere: but ‘tis mo’t certaine your husband's com-ming, with halfe Windsor at his heeles, to ſerch for ſuch a one, I come before to tell you: If you know your ſelfe cleere, why I am glad of it: but if you haue a friend here, conuey, conuey him out. Be not amaz’d, call all your ſenses to you, defend your reputation, or bid farwell to your good life for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall I do? There is a Gentleman my deere friend: and I feare not mine owne ſhame ſo much, as his perill. I had rather then a thousand pound he were out of the house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: For ſhame, neuer ſtand (you had rather, and you had rather:) your husband's heere at hand, bethinke you of ſome conueyance: in the house you cannot hide him. Oh, how haue you deceiu’d me? Looke, heere is a basket, if he be of any reasonable ſtature, he may creepe in heere, and throw fowle linnen vpon him, as if it were going to bucking: Or it is whiting time, ſend him by your two men to Datchet-Meade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: He's too big to go in there: what ſhall I do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me ſee't, let me ſee't, O let me ſee't:
Ile in, Ile in: Follow your friends counsell, Ile in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What Sir Iohn Falstaffe? Are these your Let-ters,
Knight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I loue thee, helpe mee away: let me creepe in heere: ile neuer —

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe to couer your master (Boy:) Call your men (Mist[ris]. Ford.) You diſſembling Knight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What Iohn, Robert, Iohn; Go, take vp these cloathes heere, quickly: Wher's the Cowle-staffe? Look how you drumble? Carry them to the Landreſſe in Dat-chet mead: quickly, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Pray you come nere: if I ſuspect without cause,
Why then make ſport at me, then let me be your iest,
I deserue it: How now? Whether beare you this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: To the Landreſſe forsooth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what haue you to doe whether they beare it? You were best meddle with buck-washing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Buck? I would I could wash my ſelfe of y Buck: Bucke, bucke, bucke, I bucke: I warrant you Bucke, And of the ſeason too; it ſhall appeare. Gentlemen, I haue dream’d to night, Ile tell you my dreame: heere, heere, heere bee my keyes, ascend my Chambers, ſearch, ſeeke, finde out: Ile warrant wee'le vnkennell the Fox. Let me ſtop this way first: ſo, now vncape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Good master Ford, be contented:
You wrong your ſelfe too much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: True (master Page) vp Gentlemen,
You ſhall ſee ſport anon:
Follow me Gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: This is fery fantasticall humors and iealousies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, ‘tis no-the fashion of France:
It is not iealous in France.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay follow him (Gentlemen) ſee the yſſue of his ſearch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Is there not a double excellency in this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not which pleases me better,
That my husband is deceiued, or Sir Iohn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What a taking was hee in, when your husband askt who was in the basket?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I am halfe affraid he will haue neede of washing: ſo throwing him into the water, will doe him a benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang him dishonest rascall: I would all of the ſame ſtraine, were in the ſame distreſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke my husband hath ſome ſpeciall ſuspition of Falstaffs being heere: for I neuer ſaw him ſo groſſe in his iealousie till now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I will lay a plot to try that, and wee will yet haue more trickes with Falstaffe: his diſſolute disease will ſcarse obey this medicine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall we ſend that foolishion Carion, Mist[ris]. Quickly to him, and excuse his throwing into the water, and giue him another hope, to betray him to another punishment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: We will do it: let him be ſent for to mor-row eight a clocke to haue amends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot finde him: may be the knaue bragg’d of that he could not compaſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Heard you that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: You vse me well, M[aster]. Ford? Do you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I, I do ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen make you better then your thoghts

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: You do your ſelfe mighty wrong (M[aster]. Ford)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I, I: I must beare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: If there be any pody in the house, & in the cham-bers, and in the coffers, and in the preſſes: heauen for-giue my ſins at the day of iudgement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: Be gar, nor I too: there is no-bodies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Fy, fy, M[aster]. Ford, are you not asham’d? What ſpi-rit, what diuell ſuggests this imagination? I wold not ha your distemper in this kind, for y welth of Windsor castle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis my fault (M[aster]. Page) I ſuffer for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſuffer for a pad conscience: your wife is as honeſt a o'mans, as I will desires among fiue thou-sand, and fiue hundred too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, I ſee ‘tis an honeſt woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I promisd you a dinner: come, come, walk in the Parke, I pray you pardon me: I wil hereafter make knowne to you why I haue done this. Come wife, come Mi[stris]. Page, I pray you pardon me. Pray hartly pardon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's go in Gentlemen, but (trust me) we'l mock him: I doe inuite you to morrow morning to my house to breakfast: after we'll a Birding together, I haue a fine Hawke for the bush. Shall it be ſo:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Any thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: If there is one, I ſhall make two in the Companie

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: If there be one, or two, I ſhall make-a-the turd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you go, M[aster]. Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you now remembrance to morrow on the lowsie knaue, mine Host.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Dat is good by gar, withall my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: A lowsie knaue, to haue his gibes, and his moc-keries.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Fenton, Anne, Page, Shallow, Slender, Quickly, Page, Mist. Page

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee I cannot get thy Fathers loue,
Therefore no more turne me to him (sweet Nan.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anne.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, how then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Why thou must be thy ſelfe.
He doth obiect, I am too great of birth,
And that my ſtate being gall’d with my expence,
I ſeeke to heale it onely by his wealth.
Besides these, other barres he layes before me,
My Riots past, my wilde Societies,
And tels me ‘tis a thing impoſſible
I ſhould loue thee, but as a property.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: May be he tels you true.
No, heauen ſo ſpeed me in my time to come,
Albeit I will confeſſe, thy Fathers wealth
Was the first motiue that I woo’d thee (Anne:)
Yet wooing thee, I found thee of more valew
Then ſtampes in Gold, or ſummes in ſealed bagges:
And ‘tis the very riches of thy ſelfe,
That now I ayme at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentle M[aster]. Fenton,
Yet ſeeke my Fathers loue, ſtill ſeeke it ſir,
If opportunity and humblest ſuite
Cannot attaine it, why then harke you hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Breake their talke Mistris Quickly.
My Kinsman ſhall ſpeake for himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile make a ſhaft or a bolt on't, ſlid, tis but venturing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Be not dismaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: No, ſhe ſhall not dismay me:
I care not for that, but that I am affeard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Hark ye, M[aster]. Slender would ſpeak a word with you

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I come to him. This is my Fathers choice:
O what a world of vilde ill-fauour’d faults
Lookes handsome in three hundred pounds a yeere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: And how do's good Master Fenton?
Pray you a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee's comming; to her Coz:
O boy, thou hadst a father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I had a father (M[istris]. An) my vncle can tel you good iests of him: pray you Vncle, tel Mist[ris]. Anne the iest how my Father ſtole two Geese out of a Pen, good Vnckle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris Anne, my Cozen loues you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I that I do, as well as I loue any woman in Glo-cestershire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: He will maintaine you like a Gentlewoman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I that I will, come cut and long-taile, vnder the degree of a Squire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: He will make you a hundred and fiftie pounds ioynture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anne.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Maister Shallow let him woo for him-ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie I thanke you for it: I thanke you for that good comfort: ſhe cals you (Coz) Ile leaue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anne.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Master Slender.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Now good Mistris Anne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anne.
SPEECH.LINE: What is your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: My will? Odd's-hart-lings, that’s a prettie iest indeede: I ne're made my Will yet (I thanke Hea-uen:) I am not ſuch a ſickely creature, I giue Heauen praise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anne.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane (M[aster]. Slender) what wold you with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely, for mine owne part, I would little or nothing with you: your father and my vncle hath made motions: if it be my lucke, ſo; if not, happy man bee his dole, they can tell you how things go, better then I can: you may aske your father, heere he comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Mr Slender; Loue him daughter Anne.
Why how now? What does Mr Fenten here?
You wrong me Sir, thus ſtill to haunt my house.
I told you Sir, my daughter is disposd of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay Mr Page, be not impatient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Good M[aster]. Fenton, come not to my child.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: She is no match for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, will you heare me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: No, good M[aster]. Fenton.
Come M[aster]. Shallow: Come ſonne Slender, in;
Knowing my minde, you wrong me (M[aster]. Fenton.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake to Mistris Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Mist[ris]. Page, for that I loue your daughter
In ſuch a righteous fashion as I do,
Perforce, against all checkes, rebukes, and manners,
I must aduance the colours of my loue,
And not retire. Let me haue your good will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Good mother, do not marry me to yond foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane it not, I ſeeke you a better hus-band.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: That's my master, M[aster]. Doctor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas I had rather be ſet quick i'th earth,
And bowl’d to death with Turnips.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, trouble not your ſelfe good M[aster].
Fenton, I will not be your friend, nor enemy:
My daughter will I question how ſhe loues you,
And as I finde her, ſo am I affected:
Till then, farewell Sir, ſhe must needs go in,
Her father will be angry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell gentle Mistris: farewell Nan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: This is my doing now: Nay, ſaide I, will you cast away your childe on a Foole, and a Physitian: Looke on M[aster]. Fenton, this is my doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke thee: and I pray thee once to night,
Giue my ſweet Nan this Ring: there's for thy paines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Now heauen ſend thee good fortune, a kinde heart he hath: a woman would run through fire & wa-ter for ſuch a kinde heart. But yet, I would my Maister had Mistris Anne, or I would M[aster]. Slender had her: or (in ſooth) I would M[aster]. Fenton had her; I will do what I can for them all three, for ſo I haue promisd, and Ile bee as good as my word, but ſpeciously for M[aster]. Fenton. Well, I must of another errand to Sir Iohn Falstaffe from my two Mistreſſes: what a beast am I to ſlacke it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Bardolfe I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Go, fetch me a quart of Sacke, put a tost in't. Haue I liu’d to be carried in a Basket like a barrow of butchers Offall? and to be throwne in the Thames? Wel, if I be ſeru’d ſuch another tricke, Ile haue my braines 'tane out and butter’d, and giue them to a dogge for a New-yeares gift. The rogues ſlighted me into the riuer with as little remorse, as they would haue drown’de a blinde bitches Puppies, fifteene i'th litter: and you may know by my ſize, that I haue a kinde of alacrity in ſink-ing: if the bottome were as deepe as hell, I ſhold down. I had beene drown’d, but that the ſhore was ſheluy and ſhallow: a death that I abhorre: for the water ſwelles a man; and what a thing ſhould I haue beene, when I had beene ſwel’d? I ſhould haue beene a Mountaine of Mummie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Here's M[istris]. Quickly Sir to ſpeake with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, let me poure in ſome Sack to the Thames water: for my bellies as cold as if I had ſwallow’d ſnow-bals, for pilles to coole the reines. Call her in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Come in woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: By your leaue: I cry you mercy?
Giue your worship good morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Take away these Challices:
Go, brew me a pottle of Sacke finely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bard.
SPEECH.LINE: With Egges, Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Simple of it ſelfe: Ile no Pullet-Spersme in my brewage. How now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Sir, I come to your worship from M[istris]. Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Mist[ris]. Ford? I haue had Ford enough: I was thrown into the Ford; I haue my belly full of Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas the day, (good-heart) that was not her fault: ſhe do's ſo take on with her men; they mistooke their erection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: So did I mine, to build vpon a foolish Womans promise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, ſhe laments Sir for it, that it would yern your heart to ſee it: her husband goes this morning a birding; ſhe desires you once more to come to her, be-tweene eight and nine: I must carry her word quickely, ſhe'll make you amends I warrant you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I will visit her, tell her ſo: and bidde her thinke what a man is: Let her consider his frailety, and then iudge of my merit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Do ſo. Betweene nine and ten ſaist thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Eight and nine Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, be gone: I will not miſſe her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace be with you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I meruaile I heare not of Mr Broome: he ſent me word to ſtay within: I like his money well. Oh, heere he comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Bleſſe you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Now M[aster]. Broome, you come to know
What hath past betweene me, and Fords wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: That indeed (Sir Iohn) is my busineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: M[aster]. Broome I will not lye to you,
I was at her house the houre ſhe appointed me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſped you Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Very ill-fauouredly M[aster]. Broome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſo ſir, did ſhe change her determination?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: No (M[aster]. Broome) but the peaking Curnuto her hus-band (M[aster]. Broome) dwelling in a continual larum of ielou-sie, coms me in the instant of our encounter, after we had embrast, kist, protested, & (as it were) ſpoke the prologue of our Comedy: and at his heeles, a rabble of his compa-nions, thither prouoked and instigated by his distemper, and (forsooth) to ſerch his house for his wiues Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What? While you were there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: While I was there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: And did he ſearch for you, & could not find you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall heare. As good lucke would haue it, comes in one Mist[ris]. Page, giues intelligence of Fords ap-proch: and in her inuention, and Fords wiues distraction, they conuey’d me into a bucke-basket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: A Buck-basket?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes: a Buck-basket: ram’d mee in with foule Shirts and Smockes, Socks, foule Stockings, greasie Napkins, that (Master Broome) there was the rankest compound of villanous ſmell, that euer offended no-strill. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: And how long lay you there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, you ſhall heare (Master Broome) what I haue ſufferd, to bring this woman to euill, for your good: Being thus cram’d in the Basket, a couple of Fords knaues, his Hindes, were cald forth by their Mi-stris, to carry mee in the name of foule Cloathes to Datchet-lane: they tooke me on their ſhoulders: met the iealous knaue their Master in the doore; who ask’d them once or twice what they had in their Bas-ket? I quak’d for feare least the Lunatique Knaue would haue ſearch’d it: but Fate (ordaining he ſhould be a Cuckold) held his hand: well, on went hee, for a ſearch, and away went I for foule Cloathes: But marke the ſequell (Master Broome) I ſuffered the pangs of three ſeuerall deaths: First, an intollerable fright, to be detected with a iealious rotten Bell-weather: Next to be compaſſ’d like a good Bilbo in the circum-ference of a Pecke, hilt to point, heele to head. And then to be ſtopt in like a ſtrong distillation with ſtink-ing Cloathes, that fretted in their owne grease: thinke of that, a man of my Kidney; thinke of that, that am as ſubiect to heate as butter; a man of conti-nuall diſſolution, and thaw: it was a miracle to ſcape ſuffocation. And in the height of this Bath (when I was more then halfe ſtew’d in grease (like a Dutch-dish) to be throwne into the Thames, and coold, glowing-hot, in that ſerge like a Horse-shoo; thinke of that; hiſſing hot: thinke of that (Master Broome.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: In good ſadneſſe Sir, I am ſorry, that for my ſake you haue ſufferd all this. My ſuite then is desperate: You'll vndertake her no more?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Master Broome: I will be throwne into Etna, as I haue beene into Thames, ere I will leaue her thus; her Husband is this morning gone a Birding: I haue receiued from her another ambaſſie of mee-ting: 'twixt eight and nine is the houre (Master Broome.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis past eight already Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it? I will then addreſſe mee to my appoint-ment: Come to mee at your conuenient leisure, and you ſhall know how I ſpeede: and the conclusion ſhall be crowned with your enioying her: adiew: you ſhall haue her (Master Broome) Master Broome, you ſhall cuckold Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Hum: ha? Is this a vision? Is this a dreame? doe I ſleepe? Master Ford awake, awake Master Ford: ther's a hole made in your best coate (Master Ford:) this ‘tis to be married; this ‘tis to haue Lynnen, and Buck-baskets: Well, I will proclaime my ſelfe what I am: I will now take the Leacher: hee is at my house: hee cannot ſcape me: ‘tis impoſſible hee ſhould: hee can-not creepe into a halfe-penny purse, nor into a Pepper-Boxe: But least the Diuell that guides him, ſhould aide him, I will ſearch impoſſible places: though what I am, I cannot auoide; yet to be what I would not, ſhall not make me tame: If I haue hornes, to make one mad, let the prouerbe goe with me, Ile be horne-mad.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Mistris Page, Quickly, William, Euans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Is he at M[aster]. Fords already think'st thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Sure he is by this; or will be presently; but truely he is very couragious mad, about his throwing into the water. Mistris Ford desires you to come ſo-dainely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile be with her by and by: Ile but bring my yong-man here to Schoole: looke where his Master comes; ‘tis a playing day I ſee: how now Sir Hugh, no Schoole to day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: No: Master Slender is let the Boyes leaue to play.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui
SPEECH.LINE: 'Bleſſing of his heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Hugh, my husband ſaies my ſonne pro-fits nothing in the world at his Booke: I pray you aske him ſome questions in his Accidence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither William; hold vp your head; come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Come-on Sirha; hold vp your head; an-swere your Master, be not afraid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: William, how many Numbers is in Nownes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Two.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely, I thought there had bin one Number more, because they ſay od's-Nownes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, your tatlings. What is (Faire) William?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Pulcher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Powlcats? there are fairer things then Powlcats, ſure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: You are a very ſimplicity o'man: I pray you peace. What is (Lapis) William?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: A Stone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: And what is a Stone (William?)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: A Peeble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: No; it is Lapis: I pray you remember in your praine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Lapis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: That is a good William: what is he (William) that do's lend Articles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Articles are borrowed of the Pronoune; and be thus declined. Singulariter nominatiuo hic, haec, hoc.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: Nominatiuo hig, hag, hog: pray you marke: geni-tiuo huius: Well: what is your Accusatiue-case?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Accusatiuo hinc.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you haue your remembrance (childe) Ac-cusatiuo hing, hang, hog.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang-hog, is latten for Bacon, I warrant you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: Leaue your prables (o'man) What is the Foca-tiue case (William?)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: O, Vocatiuo, O.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: Remember William, Focatiue, is caret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: And that’s a good roote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: O'man, forbeare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: What is your Genitiue case plurall (William?)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Genitiue case?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Genitiue horum, harum, horum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Vengeance of Ginyes case; fie on her; neuer name her (childe) if ſhe be a whore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: For ſhame o'man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: You doe ill to teach the childe ſuch words: hee teaches him to hic, and to hac; which they'll doe fast enough of themselues, and to call horum; fie vpon you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: O'man, art thou Lunatics? Hast thou no vn-derstandings for thy Cases, & the numbers of the Gen-ders? Thou art as foolish Christian creatures, as I would desires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Pre'thee hold thy peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Shew me now (William) ſome declensions of your
Pronounes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Forsooth, I haue forgot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: It is Qui, que, quod; if you forget your Quies, your Ques, and your Quods, you must be preeches: Goe your waies and play, go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: He is a better ſcholler then I thought he was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: He is a good ſprag-memory: Farewel Mis[tris]. Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Adieu good Sir Hugh:
Get you home boy, Come we ſtay too long.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Falstoffe, Mist. Ford, Mist. Page, Seruants, Ford, Page, Caius, Euans, Shallow

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Mi[stris]. Ford, Your ſorrow hath eaten vp my ſuffe-rance; I ſee you are obsequious in your loue, and I pro-feſſe requitall to a haires bredth, not onely Mist[ris]. Ford, in the ſimple office of loue, but in all the accustrement, complement, and ceremony of it: But are you ſure of your husband now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee's a birding (sweet Sir Iohn.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What hoa, goſſip Ford: what hoa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Step into th’ chamber, Sir Iohn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: How now (sweete heart) whose at home besides your ſelfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why none but mine owne people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: No certainly: Speake louder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly, I am ſo glad you haue no body here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why woman, your husband is in his olde lines againe: he ſo takes on yonder with my husband, ſo railes against all married mankinde; ſo curses all Eues daughters, of what complexion ſœuer; and ſo buffettes himselfe on the for-head: crying peere-out, peere-out, that any madneſſe I euer yet beheld, ſeem’d but tame-neſſe, ciuility, and patience to this his distemper he is in now: I am glad the fat Knight is not heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, do's he talke of him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Of none but him, and ſweares he was ca-ried out the last time hee ſearch’d for him, in a Basket: Protests to my husband he is now heere, & hath drawne him and the rest of their company from their ſport, to make another experiment of his ſuspition: But I am glad the Knight is not heere; now he ſhall ſee his owne foo-lerie. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: How neere is he Mistris Page?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Hard by, at ſtreet end; he wil be here anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I am vndone, the Knight is heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then you are vtterly ſham’d, & hee's but a dead man. What a woman are you? Away with him, away with him: Better ſhame, then murther.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Which way ſhould he go? How ſhould I bestow him? Shall I put him into the basket againe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Ile come no more i'th Basket:
May I not go out ere he come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas: three of Mr. Fords brothers watch the doore with Pistols, that none ſhall iſſue out: other-wise you might ſlip away ere hee came: But what make you heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall I do? Ile creepe vp into the chimney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: There they alwaies vse to discharge their
Birding-peeces: creepe into the Kill-hole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: He will ſeeke there on my word: Neyther Preſſe, Coffer, Chest, Trunke, Well, Vault, but he hath an abstract for the remembrance of ſuch places, and goes to them by his Note: There is no hiding you in the house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile go out then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: If you goe out in your owne ſemblance, you die Sir Iohn, vnleſſe you go out disguis’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: How might we disguise him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas the day I know not, there is no wo-mans gowne bigge enough for him: otherwise he might put on a hat, a muffler, and a kerchiefe, and ſo escape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Good hearts, deuise ſomething: any extremitie, rather then a mischiefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: My Maids Aunt the fat woman of Brain-ford, has a gowne aboue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: On my word it will ſerue him: ſhee's as big as he is: and there's her thrum’d hat, and her muffler too: run vp Sir Iohn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Go, go, ſweet Sir Iohn: Mistris Page and
I will looke ſome linnen for your head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Quicke, quicke, wee'le come dreſſe you ſtraight: put on the gowne the while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I would my husband would meete him in this ſhape: he cannot abide the old woman of Brain-ford; he ſweares ſhe's a witch, forbad her my house, and hath threatned to beate her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen guide him to thy husbands cud-gell: and the diuell guide his cudgell afterwards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: But is my husband comming?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I in good ſadneſſe is he, and talkes of the basket too, howsœuer he hath had intelligence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'l try that: for Ile appoint my men to carry the basket againe, to meete him at the doore with it, as they did last time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but hee'l be heere presently: let's go dreſſe him like the witch of Brainford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile first direct my men, what they ſhall doe with the basket: Goe vp, Ile bring linnen for him ſtraight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang him dishonest Varlet,
We cannot misuse enough:
We'll leaue a proofe by that which we will doo,
Wiues may be merry, and yet honeſt too:
We do not acte that often, iest, and laugh,
‘Tis old, but true, Still Swine eats all the draugh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Go Sirs, take the basket againe on your ſhoulders: your Master is hard at doore: if hee bid you ſet it downe, obey him: quickly, dispatch. 1 Ser. Come, come, take it vp. 2 Ser. Pray heauen it be not full of Knight againe. 1 Ser. I hope not, I had liefe as beare ſo much lead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but if it proue true (Mr. Page) haue you any way then to vnfoole me againe. Set downe the basket villaine: ſome body call my wife: Youth in a basket: Oh you Panderly Rascals, there's a knot: a gin, a packe, a conspiracie against me: Now ſhall the diuel be ſham’d. What wife I ſay: Come, come forth: behold what ho-nest cloathes you ſend forth to bleaching.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, this paſſes M[aster]. Ford: you are not to goe loose any longer, you must be pinnion’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, this is Lunaticks: this is madde, as a mad dogge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shall.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed M[aster]. Ford, this is not well indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſay I too Sir, come hither Mistris Ford, Mi-stris Ford, the honeſt woman, the modest wife, the vertu-ous creature, that hath the iealious foole to her husband: I ſuspect without cause (Mistris) do I?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen be my witneſſe you doe, if you ſuspect me in any dishonesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſaid Brazon-face, hold it out: Come forth ſirrah.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: This paſſes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you not asham’d, let the cloths alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall finde you anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis vnreasonable; will you take vp your wiues cloathes? Come, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Empty the basket I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why man, why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Master Page, as I am a man, there was one con-uay’d out of my house yesterday in this basket: why may not he be there againe, in my house I am ſure he is: my Intelligence is true, my iealousie is reasonable, pluck me out all the linnen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: If you find a man there, he ſhall dye a Fleas death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Heer's no man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: By my fidelity this is not well Mr. Ford: This wrongs you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: Mr Ford, you must pray, and not follow the imaginations of your owne heart: this is iealousies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, hee's not heere I ſeeke for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: No, nor no where else but in your braine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe to ſearch my house this one time: if I find not what I ſeeke, ſhew no colour for my extremity: Let me for euer be your Table-sport: Let them ſay of me, as iealous as Ford, that ſearch’d a hollow Wall-nut for his wiues Lemman. Satisfie me once more, once more ſerch with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What hoa (Mistris Page,) come you and the old woman downe: my husband will come into the Chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Old woman? what old womans that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why it is my maids Aunt of Brainford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: A witch, a Queane, an olde couzening queane: Haue I not forbid her my house. She comes of errands do's ſhe? We are ſimple men, wee doe not know what’s brought to paſſe vnder the profeſſion of Fortune-telling. She workes by Charmes, by Spels, by th’ Figure, & ſuch dawbry as this is, beyond our Element: wee know no-thing. Come downe you Witch, you Hagge you, come downe I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, good ſweet husband, good Gentle-men, let him ſtrike the old woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Come mother Prat, Come giue me your hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile Prat-her: Out of my doore, you Witch, you Ragge, you Baggage, you Poulcat, you Runnion, out, out: Ile coniure you, Ile fortune-tell you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you not asham’d?
I thinke you haue kill’d the poore woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay he will do it, ‘tis a goodly credite for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang her witch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: By yea, and no, I thinke the o'man is a witch in-deede: I like not when a o'man has a great peard; I ſpie a great peard vnder his muffler.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you follow Gentlemen, I beseech you fol-low: ſee but the iſſue of my iealousie: If I cry out thus vpon no traile, neuer trust me when I open againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's obey his humour a little further:
Come Gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Trust me he beate him mo’t pittifully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay by th’ Maſſe that he did not: he beate him mo’t vnpittifully, me thought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile haue the cudgell hallow’d, and hung ore the Altar, it hath done meritorious ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What thinke you? May we with the war-rant of woman-hood, and the witneſſe of a good consci-ence, pursue him with any further reuenge?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſpirit of wantonneſſe is ſure ſcar’d out of him, if the diuell haue him not in fee-simple, with fine and recouery, he will neuer (I thinke) in the way of waste, attempt vs againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall we tell our husbands how wee haue ſeru’d him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, by all meanes: if it be but to ſcrape the figures out of your husbands braines: if they can find in their hearts, the poore vnuertuous fat Knight ſhall be any further afflicted, wee two will ſtill bee the mini-sters. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile warrant, they'l haue him publiquely ſham’d, and me thinkes there would be no period to the iest, ſhould he not be publikely ſham’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, to the Forge with it, then ſhape it:
I would not haue things coole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, the Germane desires to haue three of your horses: the Duke himselfe will be to morrow at Court, and they are going to meet him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: What Duke ſhould that be comes ſo ſecretly?
I heare not of him in the Court: let mee ſpeake with the
Gentlemen, they ſpeake English?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir? Ile call him to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſhall haue my horses, but Ile make them pay: Ile ſauce them, they haue had my houses a week at commaund: I haue turn’d away my other guests, they must come off, Ile ſawce them, come.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Page, Ford, Mistris Page, Mistris Ford, and Euans

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis one of the best discretions of a o'man as e-uer
I did looke vpon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: And did he ſend you both these Letters at an instant?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Within a quarter of an houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me (wife) henceforth do what y wilt:
I rather will ſuspect the Sunne with gold,
Then thee with wantonnes: Now doth thy honor ſtand
(In him that was of late an Heretike)
As firme as faith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis well, ‘tis well, no more:
Be not as extreme in ſubmiſſion, as in offence,
But let our plot go forward: Let our wiues
Yet once againe (to make vs publike ſport)
Appoint a meeting with this old fat-fellow,
Where we may take him, and disgrace him for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: There is no better way then that they ſpoke of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: How? to ſend him word they'll meete him in the Parke at midnight? Fie, fie, he'll neuer come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſay he has bin throwne in the Riuers: and has bin greeuously peaten, as an old o'man: me-thinkes there ſhould be terrors in him, that he ſhould not come: Me-thinkes his flesh is punish’d, hee ſhall haue no de-sires. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: So thinke I too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Deuise but how you'l vse him whe[n] he comes,
And let vs two deuise to bring him thether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: There is an old tale goes, that Herne the
Hunter (sometime a keeper heere in Windsor Forrest)
Doth all the winter time, at ſtill midnight
Walke round about an Oake, with great rag’d-hornes,
And there he blasts the tree, and takes the cattle,
And make milch-kine yeeld blood, and ſhakes a chaine
In a mo’t hideous and dreadfull manner.
You haue heard of ſuch a Spirit, and well you know
The ſuperstitious idle-headed-Eld
Receiu’d, and did deliuer to our age
This tale of Herne the Hunter, for a truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why yet there want not many that do feare
In deepe of night to walke by this Hernes Oake:
But what of this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry this is our deuise,
That Falstaffe at that Oake ſhall meete with vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, let it not be doubted but he'll come,
And in this ſhape, when you haue brought him thether,
What ſhall be done with him? What is your plot?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: That likewise haue we thoght vpon: & thus:
Nan Page (my daughter) and my little ſonne,
And three or foure more of their growth, wee'l dreſſe
Like Vrchins, Ouphes, and Fairies, greene and white,
With rounds of waxen Tapers on their heads,
And rattles in their hands; vpon a ſodaine,
As Falstaffe, ſhe, and I, are newly met,
Let them from forth a ſaw-pit rush at once
With ſome diffused ſong: Vpon their ſight
We two, in great amazedneſſe will flye:
Then let them all encircle him about,
And Fairy-like to pinch the vncleane Knight;
And aske him why that houre of Fairy Reuell,
In their ſo ſacred pathes, he dares to tread
In ſhape prophane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: And till he tell the truth,
Let the ſupposed Fairies pinch him, ſound,
And burne him with their Tapers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: The truth being knowne,
We'll all present our ſelues; dis-horne the ſpirit,
And mocke him home to Windsor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: The children must
Be practis’d well to this, or they'll neu'r doo't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: I will teach the children their behauiours: and I will be like a Iacke-an-Apes also, to burne the Knight with my Taber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: That will be excellent,
Ile go buy them vizards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: My Nan ſhall be the Queene of all the
Fairies, finely attired in a robe of white.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſilke will I go buy, and in that time
Shall M[aster]. Slender ſteale my Nan away,
And marry her at Eaton: go, ſend to Falstaffe ſtraight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, Ile to him againe in name of Broome,
Hee'l tell me all his purpose: ſure hee'l come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Feare not you that: Go get vs properties
And tricking for our Fayries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs about it,
It is admirable pleasures, and ferry honeſt knaueries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mis.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Go Mist[ris]. Ford,
Send quickly to Sir Iohn, to know his minde:
Ile to the Doctor, he hath my good will,
And none but he to marry with Nan Page:
That Slender (though well landed) is an Ideot:
And he, my husband best of all affects:
The Doctor is well monied, and his friends
Potent at Court: he, none but he ſhall haue her,
Though twenty thousand worthier come to craue her.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Host, Simple, Falstaffe, Bardolfe, Euans, Caius, Quickly

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: What wouldst thou haue? (Boore) what? (thick ſkin) ſpeake, breathe, discuſſe: breefe, ſhort, quicke, ſnap.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simp.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Sir, I come to ſpeake with Sir Iohn Fal-staffe from M[aster]. Slender.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: There's his Chamber, his House, his Castle, his ſtanding-bed and truckle-bed: ‘tis painted about with the ſtory of the Prodigall, fresh and new: go, knock and call: hee'l ſpeake like an Anthropophaginian vnto thee: Knocke I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simp.
SPEECH.LINE: There's an olde woman, a fat woman gone vp into his chamber: Ile be ſo bold as ſtay Sir till ſhe come downe: I come to ſpeake with her indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha? A fat woman? The Knight may be robb’d:
Ile call. Bully-Knight, Bully Sir Iohn: ſpeake from thy
Lungs Military: Art thou there? It is thine Host, thine
Ephesian cals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, mine Host?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Here's a Bohemian-Tartar taries the comming downe of thy fat-woman: Let her descend (Bully) let her descend: my Chambers are honourable: Fie, priua-cy? Fie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: There was (mine Host) an old-fat-woman euen now with me, but ſhe's gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simp.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you Sir, was't not the Wise-woman of
Brainford?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I marry was it (Muſſel-shell) what would you with her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simp.
SPEECH.LINE: My Master (Sir) my master Slender, ſent to her ſeeing her go thorough the ſtreets, to know (Sir) whe-ther one Nim (Sir) that beguil’d him of a chaine, had the chaine, or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſpake with the old woman about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: And what ſayes ſhe, I pray Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſhee ſayes, that the very ſame man that beguil’d Master Slender of his Chaine, cozon’d him of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simp.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I could haue ſpoken with the Woman her ſelfe, I had other things to haue ſpoken with her too, from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: What are they? let vs know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: I: come: quicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I may not conceale them (Sir.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Conceale them, or thou di'st.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, they were nothing but about Mistris Anne Page, to know if it were my Masters fortune to haue her, or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis, ‘tis his fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: What Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: To haue her, or no: goe; ſay the woman told me ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: May I be bold to ſay ſo Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir: like who more bold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke your worship: I ſhall make my Master glad with these tydings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art clearkly: thou art clearkly (Sir Iohn) was there a wise woman with thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I that there was (mine Host) one that hath taught me more wit, then euer I learn’d before in my life: and I paid nothing for it neither, but was paid for my lear-ning. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Out alas (Sir) cozonage: meere cozonage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Where be my horses? ſpeake well of them var-letto.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Run away with the cozoners: for ſo ſoone as I came beyond Eaton, they threw me off, from behinde one of them, in a ſlough of myre; and ſet ſpurres, and away; like three Germane-diuels; three Doctor Fau-staſſes. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: They are gone but to meete the Duke (villaine) doe not ſay they be fled: Germanes are honeſt men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is mine Host?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: What is the matter Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue a care of your entertainments: there is a friend of mine come to Towne, tels mee there is three Cozen-Iermans, that has cozend all the Hosts of Reading, of Maidenhead; of Cole-brooke, of horses and money: I tell you for good will (looke you) you are wise, and full of gibes, and vlouting-stocks: and ‘tis not conuenient you ſhould be cozoned. Fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Ver' is mine Host de Iarteere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Here (Master Doctor) in perplexitie, and doubt-full delemma.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot tell vat is dat: but it is tell-a-me, dat you make grand preparation for a Duke de Iamanie: by my trot: der is no Duke that the Court is know, to come: I tell you for good will: adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Huy and cry, (villaine) goe: aſſist me Knight, I am vndone: fly, run: huy, and cry (villaine) I am vn-done. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I would all the world might be cozond, for I haue beene cozond and beaten too: if it ſhould come to the eare of the Court, how I haue beene transformed; and how my transformation hath beene washd, and cudgeld, they would melt mee out of my fat drop by drop, and liquor Fishermens-boots with me: I warrant they would whip me with their fine wits, till I were as crest-falne as a dride-peare: I neuer prosper’d, ſince I forswore my ſelfe at Primero: well, if my winde were but long enough; I would repent: Now? Whence come you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: From the two parties forsooth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: The Diuell take one partie, and his Dam the other: and ſo they ſhall be both bestowed; I haue ſuf-fer’d more for their ſakes; more then the villanous in-constancy of mans disposition is able to beare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: And haue not they ſuffer’d? Yes, I warrant; ſpe-ciously one of them; Mistris Ford (good heart) is beaten blacke and blew, that you cannot ſee a white ſpot about her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: What tell'st thou mee of blacke, and blew? I was beaten my ſelfe into all the colours of the Raine-bow: and I was like to be apprehended for the Witch of Braineford, but that my admirable dexteritie of wit, my counterfeiting the action of an old woman deliuer’d me, the knaue Constable had ſet me ith' Stocks, ith' com-mon Stocks, for a Witch. Qu, Sir: let me ſpeake with you in your Chamber, you ſhall heare how things goe, and (I warrant) to your content: here is a Letter will ſay ſomewhat: (good-hearts) what a-doe here is to bring you together? Sure, one of you do's not ſerue heauen well, that you are ſo croſſ’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal
SPEECH.LINE: Come vp into my Chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Master Fenton, talke not to mee, my minde is heauy: I will giue ouer all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet heare me ſpeake: aſſist me in my purpose,
And (as I am a gentleman) ile giue thee
A hundred pound in gold, more then your loſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: I will heare you (Master Fenton) and I will (at the least) keepe your counsell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: From time to time, I haue acquainted you
With the deare loue I beare to faire Anne Page,
Who, mutually, hath anſwer’d my affection,
(So farre forth, as her ſelfe might be her chooser)
Euen to my wish; I haue a letter from her
Of ſuch contents, as you will wonder at;
The mirth whereof, ſo larded with my matter,
That neither (singly) can be manifested
Without the ſhew of both: fat Falstaffe
Hath a great Scene; the image of the iest
Ile ſhow you here at large (harke good mine Host:)
To night at Hernes-Oke, iust 'twixt twelue and one,
Must my ſweet Nan present the Faerie-Queene:
The purpose why, is here: in which disguise
While other Iests are ſomething ranke on foote,
Her father hath commanded her to ſlip
Away with Slender, and with him, at Eaton
Immediately to Marry: She hath consented: Now Sir,
Her Mother, (euen ſtrong against that match
And firme for Doctor Caius) hath appointed
That he ſhall likewise ſhuffle her away,
While other ſports are tasking of their mindes,
And at the Deanry, where a Priest attends
Strait marry her: to this her Mothers plot
She ſeemingly obedient) likewise hath
Made promise to the Doctor: Now, thus it rests,
Her Father meanes ſhe ſhall be all in white;
And in that habit, when Slender ſees his time
To take her by the hand, and bid her goe,
She ſhall goe with him: her Mother hath intended
(The better to deuote her to the Doctor;
For they must all be mask’d, and vizarded)
That quaint in greene, ſhe ſhall be loose en-roab’d,
With Ribonds-pendant, flaring 'bout her head;
And when the Doctor ſpies his vantage ripe,
To pinch her by the hand, and on that token,
The maid hath giuen consent to go with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Which meanes ſhe to deceiue? Father, or Mo-ther.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Both (my good Host) to go along with me:
And heere it rests, that you'l procure the Vicar
To ſtay for me at Church, 'twixt twelue, and one,
And in the lawfull name of marrying,
To giue our hearts vnited ceremony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, husband your deuice; Ile to the Vicar,
Bring you the Maid, you ſhall not lacke a Priest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſhall I euermore be bound to thee;
Besides, Ile make a present recompence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Pre'thee no more pratling: go, Ile hold, this is the third time: I hope good lucke lies in odde numbers: Away, go, they ſay there is Diuinity in odde Numbers, either in natiuity, chance, or death: away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile prouide you a chaine, and Ile do what I can to get you a paire of hornes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fall.
SPEECH.LINE: Away I ſay, time weares, hold vp your head & mince. How now M[aster]. Broome? Master Broome, the mat-ter will be knowne to night, or neuer. Bee you in the Parke about midnight, at Hernes-Oake, and you ſhall ſee wonders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Went you not to her yesterday (Sir) as you told me you had appointed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I went to her (Master Broome) as you ſee, like a poore-old-man, but I came from her (Master Broome) like a poore-old-woman; that ſame knaue (Ford hir hus-band) hath the finest mad diuell of iealousie in him (Ma-ster Broome) that euer gouern’d Frensie. I will tell you, he beate me greeuously, in the ſhape of a woman: (for in the ſhape of Man (Master Broome) I feare not Goliath with a Weauers beame, because I know also, life is a Shuttle) I am in hast, go along with mee, Ile tell you all (Master Broome:) ſince I pluckt Geese, plaide Trewant, and whipt Top, I knew not what 'twas to be beaten, till lately. Follow mee, Ile tell you ſtrange things of this knaue Ford, on whom to night I will be reuenged, and I will deliuer his wife into your hand. Follow, ſtraunge things in hand (M[aster]. Broome) follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come: wee'll couch i'th Castle-ditch, till we ſee the light of our Fairies. Remember ſon Slen-der, my Slen. I forsooth, I haue ſpoke with her, & we haue a nay-word, how to know one another. I come to her in white, and cry Mum; ſhe cries Budget, and by that we know one another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: That's good too: But what needes either your Mum, or her Budget? The white will decipher her well enough. It hath ſtrooke ten a' clocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: The night is darke, Light and Spirits will be-come it wel: Heauen prosper our ſport. No man means euill but the deuill, and we ſhal know him by his hornes. Lets away: follow me.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Mist. Page, Mist. Ford, Caius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Mr Doctor, my daughter is in green, when you ſee your time, take her by the hand, away with her to the Deanerie, and dispatch it quickly: go before into the Parke: we two must go together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I know vat I haue to do, adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Fare you well (Sir:) my husband will not reioyce ſo much at the abuse of Falstaffe, as he will chafe at the Doctors marrying my daughter: But ‘tis no mat-ter; better a little chiding, then a great deale of heart-breake. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is Nan now? and her troop of Fai-ries? and the Welch-deuill Herne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: They are all couch’d in a pit hard by Hernes Oake, with obscur’d Lights; which at the very instant of Falstaffes and our meeting, they will at once display to the night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: That cannot choose but amaze him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: If he be not amaz’d he will be mock’d: If he be amaz’d, he will euery way be mock’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'll betray him finely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Against ſuch Lewdsters, and their lechery,
Those that betray them, do no treachery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: The houre drawes-on: to the Oake, to the
Oake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: Trib, trib Fairies: Come, and remember your parts: be pold (I pray you) follow me into the pit, and when I giue the watch-'ords, do as I pid you: Come, come, trib, trib.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Falstaffe, Mistris Page, Mistris Ford, Euans, Anne Page, Fairies, Page, Ford, Quickly, Slender, Fenton, Caius, Pistoll

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: The Windsor-bell hath ſtroke twelue: the Mi-nute drawes-on: Now the hot-bloodied-Gods aſſist me: Remember Ioue, thou was't a Bull for thy Europa, Loue ſet on thy hornes. O powerfull Loue, that in ſome re-spects makes a Beast a Man: in ſom other, a Man a beast. You were also (Iupiter) a Swan, for the loue of Leda: O omnipotent Loue, how nere the God drew to the com-plexion of a Goose: a fault done first in the forme of a beast, (O Ioue, a beastly fault:) and then another fault, in the ſemblance of a Fowle, thinke on't (Ioue) a fowle-fault. When Gods haue hot backes, what ſhall poore men do? For me, I am heere a Windsor Stagge, and the fattest (I thinke) i'th Forrest. Send me a coole rut-time (Ioue) or who can blame me to piſſe my Tallow? Who comes heere? my Doe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn? Art thou there (my Deere?)
My male-Deere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: My Doe, with the blacke Scut? Let the ſkie raine Potatœs: let it thunder, to the tune of Greene-sleeues, haile-kiſſing Comfits, and ſnow Eringœs: Let there come a tempest of prouocation, I will ſhelter mee heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris Page is come with me (sweet hart.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Diuide me like a brib’d-Bucke, each a Haunch: I will keepe my ſides to my ſelfe, my ſhoulders for the fellow of this walke; and my hornes I bequeath your husbands. Am I a Woodman, ha? Speake I like Herne the Hunter? Why, now is Cupid a child of conscience, he makes restitution. As I am a true ſpirit, welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, what noise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen forgiue our ſinnes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhould this be?
M.Ford. M.Page.
Away, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke the diuell wil not haue me damn’d,
Least the oyle that’s in me ſhould ſet hell on fire;
He would neuer else croſſe me thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Fairies blacke, gray, greene, and white,
You Moone-shine reuellers, and ſhades of night.
You Orphan heires of fixed destiny,
Attend your office, and your quality.
Crier Hob-goblyn, make the Fairy Oyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Elues, list your names: Silence you aiery toyes.
Cricket, to Windsor-chimnies ſhalt thou leape;
Where fires thou find'st vnrak’d, and hearths vnswept,
There pinch the Maids as blew as Bill-berry,
Our radiant Queene, hates Sluts, and Sluttery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: They are Fairies, he that ſpeaks to them ſhall die,
Ile winke, and couch: No man their workes must eie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Wher's Bede? Go you, and where you find a maid
That ere ſhe ſleepe has thrice her prayers ſaid,
Raise vp the Organs of her fantasie,
Sleepe ſhe as ſound as careleſſe infancie,
But those as ſleepe, and thinke not on their ſins,
Pinch them armes, legs, backes, ſhoulders, ſides, & ſhins.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: About, about:
Search Windsor Castle (Elues) within, and out.
Strew good lucke (Ouphes) on euery ſacred roome,
That it may ſtand till the perpetuall doome,
In ſtate as wholsome, as in ſtate ‘tis fit,
Worthy the Owner, and the Owner it.
The ſeuerall Chaires of Order, looke you ſcowre
With iuyce of Balme; and euery precious flowre,
Each faire Instalment, Coate, and ſeu'rall Crest,
With loyall Blazon, euermore be blest.
And Nightly-meadow-Fairies, looke you ſing
Like to the Garters-Compaſſe, in a ring
Th’ expreſſure that it beares: Greene let it be,
More fertile-fresh then all the Field to ſee:
And, Hony Soit Qui Mal-y-Pence, write
In Emrold-tuffes, Flowres purple, blew, and white,
Like Saphire-pearle, and rich embroiderie,
Buckled below faire Knight-hoods bending knee;
Fairies vse Flowres for their characterie.
Away, disperse: But till ‘tis one a clocke,
Our Dance of Custome, round about the Oke
Of Herne the Hunter, let vs not forget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you lock hand in hand: your ſelues in order ſet:
And twenty glow-wormes ſhall our Lanthornes bee
To guide our Measure round about the Tree.
But ſtay, I ſmell a man of middle earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauens defend me from that Welsh Fairy,
Least he transforme me to a peece of Cheese.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: Vilde worme, thou wast ore-look’d euen in thy birth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: With Triall-fire touch me his finger end:
If he be chaste, the flame will backe descend
And turne him to no paine: but if he ſtart,
It is the flesh of a corrupted hart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pist.
SPEECH.LINE: A triall, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: Come: will this wood take fire?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, oh, oh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Corrupt, corrupt, and tainted in desire.
About him (Fairies) ſing a ſcornfull rime,
And as you trip, ſtill pinch him to your time.
Fie on ſinnefull phantasie: Fie on Lust, and Luxurie:
Lust is but a bloudy fire, kindled with vnchaste desire,
Fed in heart whose flames aspire,
As thoughts do blow them higher and higher.
Pinch him (Fairies) mutually: Pinch him for his villanie.
Pinch him, and burne him, and turne him about,
Till Candles, & Star-light, & Moone-shine be out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay do not flye, I thinke we haue watcht you now: Will none but Herne the Hunter ſerue your turne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you come, hold vp the iest no higher.
Now (good Sir Iohn) how like you Windsor wiues?
See you these husband? Do not these faire yoakes
Become the Forrest better then the Towne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Sir, whose a Cuckold now? Mr Broome, Falstaffes a Knaue, a Cuckoldly knaue, Heere are his hornes Master Broome: And Master Broome, he hath enioyed nothing of Fords, but his Buck-basket, his cudgell, and twenty pounds of money, which must be paid to Mr Broome, his horses are arrested for it, Mr Broome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn, we haue had ill lucke: wee could neuer meete: I will neuer take you for my Loue againe, but I will alwayes count you my Deere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I do begin to perceiue that I am made an Aſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and an Oxe too: both the proofes are ex-tant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: And these are not Fairies: I was three or foure times in the thought they were not Fairies, and yet the guiltineſſe of my minde, the ſodaine ſurprize of my powers, droue the groſſeneſſe of the fop-pery into a receiu’d beleefe, in despight of the teeth of all rime and reason, that they were Fairies. See now how wit may be made a Iacke-a-Lent, when ‘tis vpon ill imployment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn Falstaffe, ſerue Got, and leaue your desires, and Fairies will not pinse you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſaid Fairy Hugh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: And leaue you your iealouzies too, I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I will neuer mistrust my wife againe, till thou art able to woo her in good English.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue I laid my braine in the Sun, and dri’de it, that it wants matter to preuent ſo groſſe ore-reaching as this? Am I ridden with a Welch Goate too? Shal I haue a Coxcombe of Frize? Tis time I were choak’d with a peece of toasted Cheese.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Seese is not good to giue putter; your belly is al putter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Seese, and Putter? Haue I liu’d to ſtand at the taunt of one that makes Fritters of English? This is e-nough to be the decay of lust and late-walking through the Realme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Sir Iohn, do you thinke though wee would haue thrust vertue out of our hearts by the head and ſhoulders, and haue giuen our ſelues without ſcru-ple to hell, that euer the deuill could haue made you our delight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What, a hodge-pudding? A bag of flax?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: A puft man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Old, cold, wither’d, and of intollerable en-trailes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: And one that is as ſlanderous as Sathan?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: And as poore as Iob?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: And as wicked as his wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: And giuen to Fornications, and to Tauernes, and Sacke, and Wine, and Metheglins, and to drinkings and ſwearings, and ſtarings? Pribles and prables?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I am your Theame: you haue the ſtart of me, I am deiected: I am not able to anſwer the Welch Flannell, Ignorance it ſelfe is a plummet ore me, vse me as you will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Sir, wee'l bring you to Windsor to one Mr Broome, that you haue cozon’d of money, to whom you ſhould haue bin a Pander: ouer and aboue that you haue ſuffer’d, I thinke, to repay that money will be a bi-ting affliction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet be cheerefull Knight: thou ſhalt eat a pos-set to night at my house, wher I will desire thee to laugh at my wife, that now laughes at thee: Tell her Mr Slen-der hath married her daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Doctors doubt that;
If Anne Page be my daughter, ſhe is (by this) Doctour
Caius wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Whoa hœ, hœ, Father Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Sonne? How now? How now Sonne,
Haue you dispatch’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Dispatch’d? Ile make the best in Glostershire know on't: would I were hang’d la, else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Of what ſonne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I came yonder at Eaton to marry Mistris Anne Page, and ſhe's a great lubberly boy. If it had not bene i'th Church, I would haue ſwing’d him, or hee ſhould haue ſwing’d me. If I did not thinke it had beene Anne Page, would I might neuer ſtirre, and ‘tis a Post-masters Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon my life then, you tooke the wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: What neede you tell me that? I think ſo, when I tooke a Boy for a Girle: If I had bene married to him, (for all he was in womans apparrell) I would not haue had him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why this is your owne folly,
Did not I tell you how you ſhould know my daughter,
By her garments?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I went to her in greene, and cried Mum, and ſhe cride budget, as Anne and I had appointed, and yet it was not Anne, but a Post-masters boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Good George be not angry, I knew of your purpose: turn’d my daughter into white, and in-deede ſhe is now with the Doctor at the Deanrie, and there married.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Ver is Mistris Page: by gar I am cozoned, I ha married oon Garsoon, a boy; oon pesant, by gar. A boy, it is not An Page, by gar, I am cozened.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why? did you take her in white?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I bee gar, and ‘tis a boy: be gar, Ile raise all
Windsor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: This is ſtrange: Who hath got the right Anne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: My heart misgiues me, here comes Mr Fenton.
How now Mr Fenton?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anne.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon good father, good my mother pardon

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Mistris:
How chance you went not with Mr Slender?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why went you not with Mr Doctor, maid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: You do amaze her: heare the truth of it,
You would haue married her mo’t ſhamefully,
Where there was no proportion held in loue:
The truth is, ſhe and I (long ſince contracted)
Are now ſo ſure that nothing can diſſolue vs:
Th’ offence is holy, that ſhe hath committed,
And this deceit looses the name of craft,
Of disobedience, or vnduteous title,
Since therein ſhe doth euitate and ſhun
A thousand irreligious cursed houres
Which forced marriage would haue brought vpon her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand not amaz’d, here is no remedie:
In Loue, the heauens themselues do guide the ſtate,
Money buyes Lands, and wiues are ſold by fate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad, though you haue tane a ſpecial ſtand to ſtrike at me, that your Arrow hath glanc’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, what remedy? Fenton, heauen giue thee ioy, what cannot be eschew’d, must be embrac’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: When night-dogges run, all ſorts of Deere are chac’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I will muse no further: Mr Fenton,
Heauen giue you many, many merry dayes:
Good husband, let vs euery one go home,
And laugh this ſport ore by a Countrie fire,
Sir Iohn and all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it be ſo (Sir Iohn:)
To Master Broome, you yet ſhall hold your word,
For he, to night, ſhall lye with Mistris Ford:
